149838660.review:
Antichamber is a game I've tried to play over and over in the ten years since its release. The same thing happens each time, I play for ten minutes or so and am drawn in by the (still) unique non-euclidean lateral puzzles before running headfirst into the true mechanics: block puzzles. 

And what a truly mixed bag of block puzzles they are. Antichamber contains within it one of the worst puzzle tools featured in any game. The block gun is finicky and so deeply frustrating to use and is such a slap in the face after a truly intriguing opening. After the elegant opening that demands you question your assumptions and truly observe cause and effect in this strange world, there follows only sloppy, linear logic cube puzzles where you're likely to get stuck because the game just didn't even try to explain one of its new mechanics. Fans might rebut that last point. "Well the mechanics *are* the puzzle, stupid" That might fly with the Witness, which constantly prompts you be creative and try new solutions (or to piss off till later when you've learned more), here there are tutorials that explain about half the mechanics of a new tool, leaving the rest for you to stumble upon by pure happenstance.

Honestly it just becomes a slog, not helped by the complete lack of narrative motivation. There are hints and teases at the start: a mysterious black entity floats through unreachable corridors, mere inches away. These soon become just as absent as the lateral puzzles within the first half-hour, only showing up again at the honestly pretty dull conclusion. What you're left with are throwaway doodles with fortune cookie aphorisms, all as empty as the walls they occupy. These were cute a decade ago, but now just seem patronisingly low effort. The visuals too at first seem elegantly simplistic, but are eventually gratingly basic. It all feels low effort, when games like Baba Is You can utilise visual simplicity whilst manufacturing a unique and charming aesthetic, Antichamber is just empty. Narratively, visually, aurally, mechanically hollow. I can't bring myself to hate or even dislike Antichamber, but then I can't bring myself to like it either. A promising concept followed only by disappointment, it has been thoroughly surpassed by its puzzling successors.

Antichamber is a game that messes with your head!  If you thought you knew how to beat puzzle games then you'll need to think again.  You are actually inside the game equivalent of an M. C. 147963737.review:
Antichamber is a puzzle game developed by an artist, not a game designer, and it shows.
If you are here to play a Portal like, you will experience only a few puzzles that capture the same level of thought and consideration that Portal did. 
This is due to the conflicting nature of the themes in display. The art direction shows visual themes of absurdism and cubism and these are the only two elements that align with the strange puzzling tool of the cube gun. 
Every other element beyond this clash. From game play point of view, the main theme of the puzzles is to learn through sheer determination and very few hints. These hints are purposefully vague and even outright disrespectful to the player in their crass ways of saying "pay more attention" over 40 times. Many of these puzzles connect to each other, but due to the non-linear and non-euclidean design of the game, hints for puzzles you learned earlier may not be easily remembered. Specifically a strange mechanic explored and taught in one puzzle, is critical for another and critical for the finale. The good puzzles are quite enjoyable, and if the game were just about the puzzles, this would be a good review because I have a fondness for games that push players to experiment to learn.

But this is all ruined by the art direction and its' themes. Antichamber is a contemporary art piece, one that has interesting cubist designs with plenty of absurdism. Unfortunately, one of its' primary themes is to have highly saturated, contrasting colors that are harmful to the eyes. These are not toned down at any point of the game, often filling the space with sickening colors that make it difficult to look at.
This still would not be too much of a detriment if they had leaned into a greater theme about contemporary art. Contemporary art is often difficult to look at and even harder to find reason to analyze to the common viewer. The highly saturated colors with high contrast follows this, and the difficulty of the puzzles acting as a game play based metaphor for digging deeper into the themes of the often convoluted and complex themes of modern and contemporary art.
But unfortunately, there is no payoff for digging deeper into Antichamber. There is no larger themes, there are no deeper meanings. The absurdist art pieces and areas do nothing but confuse and mislead the player, detracting from game play and making difficult to tell what is part of the game and what is part of the art. This is further compounded by the endless text boxes that wax on philosophically in very generalized manners, as if the artist had no overall intent with the art direction.

In summary, Antichamber feels like a wealth of game play potential that is held down by the conflicting contemporary designs. As an art piece, it appears that they wanted to capture the deeper themes of similar works of art, but with little of the effort or purpose in their design.

147686381.review:
Antichamber is more of an audio-visual experience than a puzzle game although there are certainly puzzles in the traditional sense. The main difficulty lies in navigating through what seems to be an ever shifting maze and figuring out the rules of the game and the rules that are meant to be bent. The ambient OST is perfect for the setting and enhances the dream-like atmosphere.

There's no hand holding, no telling you where to go, whether you're making any progress and how the game works. That's the biggest challenge. And while that's why I've grown to really appreciate it, those also might be the same reasons why someone who likes more straightforward puzzle games such as Portal, The Talos Principle or the Witness might be put off by it. The game really encourages you to tinker and mess around with the tools that you get and explore your surroundings. Above all, it encourages an inquisitive mind. Admittedly, I was close to dropping the game at first because of its more abstract nature but once you start to understand the logic behind it, it becomes very enjoyable. Now that the journey is over I wish I enjoyed my stay longer.

147078169.review:
Antichamber is a pretty good puzzle game.  With very few instructions, the game teaches you the concepts you need.  The map feels like a fractal.  It's hard to tell if you're going the right direction.  But you can jump around the map by clicking a minimap.  Sometimes you'll walk somewhere and can't walk back, and feel forced to use the minimap, and it feels like you're getting betrayed by the game.

Antichamber usually rides the fine line of puzzles being difficult enough that you feel a sense of accomplishment, but not getting stuck.  I felt stuck once or twice.  Early on, it wasn't always clear when I didn't have the right stuff to complete a puzzle.

You're not gonna get photorealistic gfx, but you forget about that in a few minutes.  And it's quite useful to have a minimalist-style game because it's more clear what's part of the puzzle, and what's not.

I hit a few visual bugs during the game, a couple clipping bugs, and even caused it to crash once. Even set to 1920x1080 (my monitor resolution) it felt scaled-up.

There's little to no story, but I don't care.

I recommend Antichamber if you like games like Portal, Infinifactory, and The Witness.

146217780.review:
Without a shadow of a doubt one of the best puzzle games I have played. Antichamber takes a difficult concept and really delivers well on it. There are a few questionable design choices and puzzle designs in the game, but when Antichamber is taken as a whole those decisions start to make sense. Antichamber is a constantly evolving experience that grows and morphs as you learn more about it. The game you play when you start is fundamentally different from the game you play when you're ready to tackle the final level, and most of it hinges on the things you learn as you go. 

Antichamber is equal parts a puzzle game and a philosophical journey that teaches you about game mechanics, as well as life, with its simple but effective means of communication. The level design is open ended and doesn't offer much in terms of a clear goal, but if you take the hints the game offers there is a strong sense of direction. The experience is not rooted in mechanical skill and the levels can be completed at your own leisure. (Although there are a handful, less than 5, jumping-related challenges that require rather good timing to beat.)

Due to the open ended nature of the design I did have several moments where I felt like a puzzle didn't have any apparent solutions. But the game actively encourages you to leave problems that are too hard for later, and I felt a great sense of accomplishment and satisfaction from coming back to an "impossible" problem with newfound knowledge that made progress trivial. I would sum up Antichamber to be a continuous series of "things just clicking", more so than other puzzle games of the same nature (such as Portal). You will get stuck, and the game is designed around starting over or trying something else.

The sound design is solid. The visuals are clear and effective, although I wish it had better anti-aliasing. The art style is very much "programmer art", but it still feels inviting and charming. Controls are logical and the game feels good to play. No major complaints about the technical aspects.

I managed to complete the game in roughly 6-7 hours without looking up any walk-throughs or tutorials. However, there was 1 puzzle that I only managed to finish by dumb luck [spoiler] It involved walking through a series of solid walls in a non-euclidean space at the top of the "tower"[/spoiler]. There were 2 optional rooms I wasn't able to connect by the time I finished my play-through, but I still feel like I had the full Antichamber experience without missing anything.

In conclusion: Antichamber is a game about learning to play Antichamber. In the same way that the levels bend back into themselves in impossible ways, the game is both incoherent and perfectly legible. Often leaving you completely on your own while holding your hand. It lets you outsmart it while still always being one step ahead of you. It even made me go back in time and retroactively appreciate moments when I was feeling boundlessly frustrated. It's hard to call something that is only 10 years old timeless, but I feel like Antichamber will survive the test of time.

It's not for everyone, but for some people, it will be everything. 8.9/10

145754874.review:
Antichamber can easily rank up as one of the all time greats in the first person puzzle genre, even with such fierce competition such as Portal, Myst, Superliminal and The Witness. This game was another title that came out on the wake of Portal's release as another game within the "test chamber" subgenre with a small distinction of having more focus on exploration, something I would perhaps compare to the more modern The Witness. Non-euclidean logic that will blow your mind and test your comprehension skills and critical thinking, packed in a minimalist game which is as efficient as it can be in order to communicate the game's concept and ideas. Everything in the game is intended and serves a unique purpose, even the "main hub" and the way "saves" work. Uniquely original puzzles that many would consider mind-benders will prove to be a puzzle game fan's dream, or nightmare. I'm glad Steam does not have achievements for this game as this would've ruined the sense of exploration and discovery that this game has. This is a 10/10 and a game I can see myself coming back to.

On a technical side... this game does not count with Steam Cloud so you'll have to copy and paste the saves yourself. The game won't be saved if you force quit either, please read how to save in the main hub instruction so you don't lose your progress. The minimalist graphics and great use of silence (both visual and auditory) make the presentation of this game pretty timeless unlike a lot of its contemporaries. It can literally run in 10 year old college laptops, hell, it can even run in old mid 2000s office desktops and it would still run great with an appropriate selection of available resolutions.

If you're a fan of puzzle games, especially First Person Exploratory Puzzle games and/or "Test Chamber" Puzzle games then you owe it to yourself to play this game. It is rare for me to find a game that does so much with so little by simply having excellent comprehension of what game design is supposed to be. If you DON'T like puzzle games then you can stay away from this game as you will find yourself frustrated.

145187325.review:
[b]TLDR[/b] Early physics-based puzzle platformer, interesting puzzles and concept but lacks the depth of later entries.  [15/20⭐, 10h🏅, 2/5💡]

[b]Context[/b] Antichamber is one of the “test chamber” puzzle platform games that came out in the wake of Portal, taking place in an abstract setting (think, for instance, of [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/macwh/recommended/239430/]Q.U.B.E.[/url] before the Director’s Cut). Although the main puzzles rely on simple mechanics, the twist is handling the impossible physics that permeate the levels.

[b]Writing[/b] There is no plot, and we never gets to know what we are doing, nor why. When you solve a puzzle, a “life advice” aphorism is provided that relates to the strategy required to beat the level.

[b]Aesthetics[/b] Visuals are simple and abstract, without any kind of detail, as typical in these “test chamber” games. [spoiler]The rigidity of the design is evident by the ending when we finally see something that are not straight lines.[/spoiler] Again, this is similar to [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/macwh/recommended/239430/]Q.U.B.E.]Q.U.B.E.[/url]. The ambient style soundtrack is pretty good, although it’s often not clear how the tense/relaxed tones of the tracks relate to the actual game. There is no voice acting.

[b]Gameplay[/b] For all the emphasis on the mind-bending aspects of the world, the actual puzzle mechanics were rather straightforward. They mostly involve manipulating cubes using guns with increasingly complex powers [spoiler](from creation, to movement, to multiplication)[/spoiler]. The impossible physics were mostly relevant for exploring and navigating between the levels [spoiler](including paths leading back to themselves, or paths that change depending on the perspective)[/spoiler]. Continuing the comparison with Q.U.B.E., the puzzle-solving mechanics feel similar, but the exploration part is much less action-oriented. The game is not particularly hard despite the impossible physics, since the interactions possible interactions with the word are limited.

There’s a main hub that allows quick travelling to the levels, and also identifies unsolved levels and missed paths (but not missed messages), which also made the game considerably easier. Some of these levels require carrying something from other levels, and due to the way the (impossible) way the levels are connected, this often requires starting from other levels. 

One aspect of the game that was a bit frustrating is some kind of secret puzzle (involving the pink cubes) that has no purpose and seems to have been left unfinished (or was this the intended effect?).

You can hit deadends, and you’ll just have to return to the hub and re-start the puzzle. There are no deaths or gameovers [spoiler](the count-down timer is there just to mess with the player).[/spoiler]. The overall progress is saved but not of each level, which resets when you return to the hub.	

[b]Value[/b] It took me 10h to completely beat the game (i.e., solve all levels and get all messages), amounting to about 60 puzzles. Honestly, the price tag seems a bit steep for a game of this depth and age. There is a single progress slot, but you can always revisit previous chapters. You can tackle the levels in non-linear fashion, but there is a single ending. There are no achievements other than the in-game registry of found messages. If you missed some, you can just revisit the levels looking for them. I can see this being replayed only to revisit the puzzles.

142998919.review:
Antichamber is a game about  thinking outside the box, because when you turn around, there is no box. 

The way the way the game builds on your mechanical skills and understanding of it's systems is nothing short of genius. There were times where I was downright baffled that they seriously expected people to figure it out on their own, in an impressive feat of respect towards their players. If you want a incredibly creative puzzle game that respects your intelligence while giving you genuinely heartfelt and meaningful messages which double as hints throughout, this game will deliver on your expectations and more.

142801382.review:
Antichamber is a puzzle game that plays with non-euclidean geometry, perspective, and an unusual gadget, to create environmental puzzles in a world that feels like a cross between a modern art museum and test laboratory.

The minimalist art style uses splashes of colour and sound to help you navigate its labyrinthine black and white halls as facing and movement are turned into novel game mechanics.  It might sound dizzying but it's applied in a gentle way that makes the world abstract without becoming disorienting. Plus you can always teleport back to the entrance and use the map to restore your sense of direction if you need it.

Each puzzle is accompanied by motivational phrases and tid-bits of advice that punctuate the lesson it aimed to teach turning each challenge into a physical metaphor. The solutions tend to build on one another so it feels like you're learning the rules of the space as you play and explore, best exemplified by the cube tool. I can't get into much more detail than that without spoiling things but the puzzles are interesting and unconventional.

If you enjoy spatial logic puzzles Antichamber has a few hours of fun for you to delve into. It's not a hard game and some solutions can be tedious to implement, but the visuals, environment, and creative gameplay make this title stand out as a memorable experience.

Sometimes in the course of a conversation somebody will say a thing that completely kills all further discussion of the issue because ...there just isn't anything left to say after it's been said as succinctly as it can be.

If culture is a conversation in some sense, and videogames specifically be held as a part of that culture then "Antichamber" is the conversation killing comment to end the discussion about what a puzzle game could be in IDEAL.

If a player is truly willing to engage the game intellectually in a thoughtful manner (as I believe it is meant to be engaged) that player will walk away having learned LIFE PRINCIPLES, and they will continue to contemplate them even after they have stopped playing. Of course if a player doesn't want to play it like this then they may get none of this out of the game and for such players this is not a good game to play and would be seen as nothing but a puzzle game that isn't as flashy as others.

So really there is no way for me to rate it thumbs up or thumbs down exclusively because depending on what kind of gamer you are it's really either of these, but for my money it was game worth buying and a work of art...perhaps philosophy.

141864866.review: Antichamber is one of the best first-person puzzle games I've ever played, and it's tempting to say I like it more than Portal.  Playing through this game and soaking in the atmosphere conveyed by its minimalist graphics and zen-like music and ambiance is.... an experience.  It's also worth mentioning this plays like a metroidvania, with non-linear exploration and being able to re-explore previously visited areas once you acquire more abilities, and this is incredibly satisfying.  The game also messes with your mind in strange and surreal ways time and time again.  These sorts of mental shenanigans are a little more common in games in recent years (e.g. Superliminal), but Antichamber was unique in this regard when it first came out (at least to my knowledge).  This is a good one.  Super recommend!

141588960.review:
A short puzzle game in which you explore and interact with abstract spaces that often subvert your expectations.

[hr][/hr]
Puzzles aren’t too hard but manage to stay entertaining throughout the game. Some will require you to think outside the box, but everything should be manageable. As the game progresses, you’ll gain and expand the ability to place cubes, which is used for most puzzles, although I usually found these to be inferior to the more unique puzzles detached from this mechanic.

You’re guided through the game somewhat by following an entity, which along with the finale it moves you towards give Antichamber a hint of an abstract story. Each puzzle solved also unveils a basic line art image with a fitting adage, giving you something to collect.

The game’s timeless graphics certainly stand out and the design of some of the rooms you traverse is certainly mesmerizing, giving the game a very unique vibe. Sadly, there are some elements and paths left in the game that were never finished and may leave you disappointed with their lack of resolution.

[hr][/hr]
All in all, Antichamber is a neat little puzzle game about exploring an alien world and having conceptions challenged. It’s rather short but certainly worth experiencing for some of the tricks it pulls on you alone.

139040043.review:
I purchased this game a while ago and played it for several hours. However, I encountered a challenging section and later had to format my PC. Since this release doesn't support cloud saving, I simply made the decision to move on and forget about it

Recently, however, while I was browsing through my library, I decided to give it another chance. I must say, it is one of the most unconventional games I have ever played

Let's discuss the starting point. Initially, you have no knowledge of your identity or objective, except for the task of solving highly unusual puzzles. As you explore your surroundings, your experience grows, and you unlock some tools to assist you in different situations

There are subtle hints scattered throughout the map, always presented in illustrations. While some of these hints prove useful, others can be quite philosophical and / or cryptic. The graphics, while simple, are adequate, and the sound effects and music contribute to an immersive experience, creating an atmosphere of anticipation for the unexpected

The puzzles are genuinely clever, and although some of them require time and effort to solve, particularly when integrating elements of the first-person shooter genre, the sense of satisfaction upon completion is truly gratifying

In conclusion, if you appreciate puzzle games and enjoy unconventional experiences, I believe you will find this experience to be quite enjoyable

136705945.review:
Antichamber es uno de esos valientes títulos que ni está creado para todo el mundo, ni mucho menos lo pretende, más bien todo lo contrario. El juego trata al jugador con un desdén apoteósico, eliminando cualquier tipo de ayuda, pista, o guía de lo que debemos hacer. Al lado de este juego, The Witness te lleva en brazos a la cama, te arropa y te da un beso de buenas noches.
El juego empieza con un menú con un letrero que dice "Esto es todo lo que necesitas saber" con los controles y poco más, a partir de ahí vas por libre explorando algunos de los escenarios más abstractos que recuerdo en un videojuego. Al igual que Manifold Garden, el juego se basa en geometría no euclidiana, pero es que el juego no contento con eso, no se corta en ningún momento de hacerle “trampas” al jugador en plan, ese pasillo por el que acabas de llegar, como le pierdas de vista ya no es el mismo pasillo y es otro totalmente diferente que te lleva a otro sitio en la otra punta del mapa, por lo que como no prestes algo de atención no te enteraras ni como has llegado a algunos sitios. Además, el escenario es una suerte de mundo abierto, el juego no es lineal del todo.
El juego tiene un mapa en la sala que hace de menú principal, el cual nos dirá en que sala del mapa estamos y cuantas “salidas” tiene cada sala, es de las poquísimas ayudas que nos dará el juego. 
En cuanto a mecánicas, a medida que vayamos avanzando el juego se nos proporcionara una “pistola” con la que podemos “absorber” material en forma de cubos y después expulsarlo para mantener puertas abiertas, hacer puentes, o lo que sea que tengamos que hacer.


El juego exige de mucha paciencia y predisposición por parte del jugador, es por ello que no es adecuado para todo el mundo, de hecho me gustaría saber la tasa de finalización del juego, pero como el juego no tiene ningún logro no se puede saber, pero estoy seguro de que debe ser BAJÍSIMA.
Nada de esto lo estoy contemplando como algo negativo, y menos en esta época donde nos dan absolutamente todo masticado y nos llevan de la mano, y donde el jugador medio en cuanto tiene que estar unos minutos buscando una solución a un problema, ya tira de guía, o directamente abandona. De hecho, The Witness, este Antichamber o el propio Outer Wilds hacen lo que pocos juegos se atreven a hacer, no tratar al jugador de deficiente mental.


Lo que no me ha gustado mucho es que por lo que vi durante las 11 horas que me ha durado completarlo, muchas “salas” realmente no sirven para nada, haces los rompecabezas que te exigen y realmente aparentemente muchos solo son para pura satisfacción personal, pues son callejones sin salida. De hecho, algunas salas deben ser totalmente opcionales, pues me he terminado el juego y aún me quedaban al menos 5 o 6 salas que no he visitado (por no saber como acceder). Deberían de “recompensar” de alguna manera al jugador para incentivarle a hacer los puzzles.
Eso sí, el juego te hace ser creativo como pocos juegos logran, algunos puzzles los he pasado sin saber si es el modo correcto de hacerlo, no sé si es como el desarrollador ideó, pero gracias las mecánicas que tiene el juego te hace hacer virguerías, sobre todo con las mecánicas de construcción, las cuales me parecen muy originales y bien resueltas.

En cuanto al apartado gráfico, el juego es muy minimalista, casi todo es en blanco y negro, salvo algunos colores y mucho cubismo. A destacar la “aparente” infinidad de cubos que podremos colocar por el escenario... yo al menos no he llegado al tope, el cual entiendo que en algún número alto estará.
El sonido muy anecdótico y relajante, como suele ser habitual en esta clase de títulos.

Y en cuanto a la historia, pues literalmente no tiene historia, me da igual lo que se pueda leer por alguna wiki del juego, o fumadas extrasensoriales de personas en internet con sombreros de papel de plata en sus casas comentando el juego... esto no tiene historia. Es aún más extremo que The Witness en este sentido.

En definitiva, Antichamber es un grandísimo juego de puzzles, casi al nivel de los grandes exponentes al género (The Witness, Talos Principle, The Filament, Portal 2, etc) pero que es tan hardcore que estoy seguro de que no mucha gente va a disfrutar con él. Además, la ausencia total de historia realmente no le hace ningún bien, pues mucha gente igual le daría una oportunidad si al menos tuviese una historia interesante, pero es TAN gafa pasta en este sentido que si tuviese una historia más tradicional, seguro que más jugadores lo terminarían.

PD:Juego jugado integramente en Steam Deck

135564582.review:
This is a game that's hard to compare to anything... for the first half. Then it feels a lot like Portal. And therein lies the problem. Because the beginning of this game has some of the weirdest, trippiest, operating-on-dream-logic charm of anything I've ever played. The solutions to puzzles often make no logical sense, yet in another, more emotional way, they make perfect sense. Everything just somehow feels right. It was always very satisfying when I figured something out, even if I didn't quite know why something worked. Especially when I didn't. Then I found the portal gun.

Okay, it's not a gun that shoots portals, but it looks similar to the eponymous device, which makes comparisons between these two puzzles games kind of inevitable. The gameplay mechanics are actually very different and unique. The real issue is that the mechanics feel so... mechanical. Everything in the game becomes very logical and rational from the moment you pick up the gun. It's a stark contrast to how flowing and natural and other-worldly everything feels in the first half of the game. The sense of child-like wonder disappears and is replaced by something that just feels a lot more mundane. I eventually grew bored with the later game and re-started it to experience the first half again.

So, should you try it? Yes. You should. You won't forget it. But, depending on what you look for in a game, you might not enjoy all parts of it equally.

135510144.review:
A psychedelic, surrealist, non-euclidean masterpiece from the early 10s that exemplifies what "indie" has come to mean today. 

Its so-hard-you-can-only-solve-'em-just-when-you're-about-to-give-up puzzles are paired with contextually relevant axioms of philosophy and musings on life, which are a new set of puzzles of their own, ones that require a completely different mental dimension to process. Aside from the writing, the artstyle is functional, yet still exhibits stylistic flair. The soundtrack is peacefully ambient, yet still experiments with what situational abstract detail it can communicate (those wind chimes). The gameplay also includes experimental choices that -- overall -- just feel "right" and contribute to its themes of self-discovery and exploration, like the quick escape to the main menu (which also happens to exist within the game world and is not simply relegated to a UI system). The entire game exudes all the love Bruce managed to stuff in over the many years he slaved over it.

If the dev happens to read, please do what you can to make launching the game less clunky (it has driven some people away, rightfully so), and porting the signs over to achievements would be absolutely awesome! Thank you for all the work you've done to get this game published and best of luck on your next title!

133043147.review:
This puzzle game uses the perspective a lot to fool the players, and they managed to keep the puzzles refreshing till the very end.

I got really familiar with the map as I progressed, and I enjoyed backtracking & uncovering new chunks of the map as I got new guns with new powers.
The use of the cubes to clear some of the puzzles was always really clever!

I liked how they handled the progression. You can go back to the main hub whenever you want to teleport somewhere else, and your game saves automatically everytime you uncover a new part of the map.
So you never feel like you're hardstuck or wasting your time.
When you're struggling with a puzzle, you can always go check many of the other rooms to try and clear new paths.

It felt really rewarding to figure out the less obvious game mechanics, such as generating more cubes with the green gun.
Some puzzles were tough to figure out for me personally. If you're afraid of games being too easy, or too hand-holdy, don't worry. That's clearly not the case with Antichamber.

8/10

132298305.review:
[h1]Antichamber Review[/h1]

[hr][/hr]

Antichamber is a first-person puzzle game that takes place in a strange and mind-bending world. Players must navigate through a series of increasingly difficult challenges, using their wits and problem-solving skills to uncover the truth behind this strange world.

The game's graphics are simple, but effective, and the environments are expertly designed to challenge players in new and unexpected ways. The puzzles themselves are creative and thought-provoking, requiring players to think outside the box and see the world in a different way.

One of the standout features of Antichamber is its clever use of perspective and scale. Players must often reorient themselves and see the world in new ways in order to progress. This keeps the game feeling fresh and exciting, and helps to prevent boredom from setting in.

The game's atmosphere is mysterious and enigmatic, adding to the overall experience. The game is also very short, so players can experience the entire game in one sitting.

[h1]Scoring:[/h1]

Puzzle Design: 9/10
Graphics: 7/10
Atmosphere: 8/10
Length: 6/10
Replayability: 7/10

[h1]Overall Score: 7.6/10[/h1]

131999919.review:
I had purchased this game years ago and tinkered around with it but never got around to completion; now, on the game's ten year anniversary I stumbled across it again (by sheer coincidence) and decided to play it. I'm quite obsessed with non-euclidean illusory game design, and the sections of the game that use that shine the best, but about a third of the way through you gain a 'matter gun' which becomes the focus of pretty much all the gameplay. The gun is extremely tedious to use and the puzzles that come with it are no better. Unfortunately this is the direction the game heavily leans toward at this point with little attention given to putting in some more impressive 'mind-bending' design. Also, although I like those mind-bending sections, it's clear that that style was incredibly underdeveloped a decade ago and most of the implementation loses the novelty it must have had back then. (Also also, a select few puzzles are just downright cruel in how little clue there is to how you solve them...)

I also hated how the game was both environmentally non-linear AND had no real direction. This leaves you wandering around the map for hours, in an environment which is very tiring to navigate, trying to find what you might be able to solve next, unsure if you just don't have the right gun yet, you aren't smart enough to solve the puzzle, or you literally just haven't touched a wall the right way. The plain visuals don't help make this exploration any less exhausting, nor do the quite underwhelming little morals/'hints'. I know there is an interactive wall map that supposedly shows you where you're missing spots, but it's so vaguely designed that it doesn't help at all. What is the difference between a rectangular hallway end, a circular hallway end, and an arrow? Which one of those should I be looking at? The game refuses to explain. There's also little arrows that appear on the walls and floor sometimes but as far as I can tell those are moreso hints for navigating certain 'mind-bending' architecture, not pointing out areas you haven't explored yet.

Antichamber has aged Very poorly and I wouldn't recommend playing it unless you ADORE the visual style and consider your patience with these puzzles to be limitless. Even so, I still feel this game is genuinely important to gaming history, and that is something to be proud of.

131827824.review:
REVIEW #32
Antichamber
----------

Let me start by stating that this is the first time that I've reviewed a single-player-only game without completing at least the main scenario or campaign. I've owned Antichamber for years, and I've always really wanted to conquer it but ended up stopping fairly early in the game every time that I tried. I recently gave the game another shot, only to yet again lose interest in it and quit playing. It wasn't until a week or two later that, after all this time, I finally had a revelation: no matter how much I want to, I do not like this game.

I feel like I SHOULD like this game. It's a first-person puzzle game with a simple-yet-abstract visual style and think-outside-of-the-box brain teasers to conquer, and all of these elements are exciting and interesting to me. Also, the game is solidly designed: I never ran into a bug or technical issue, and the visuals, sounds and background ambiances are interesting and well-rendered.

Additionally, as far as I've gotten in the game, a majority of the puzzles (while ranging in difficulty) seemed understandable and like all of the information that you had to solve them was either given to you already or just around the next corner, so to speak. (With that said, there was a couple of puzzles that I seemingly solved by sheer coincidence, leaving me confused and with no clue as to what I just did to advance in the game.) The puzzles are usually presented as different rooms and sections of a giant world that you're exploring. If you hit ESC during the game, you're transported to a main room that contains a large map, showing what puzzles you've unlocked and/or completed. You can use this map to quick-travel to almost any place that you've been to, which is handy if a puzzle stumps you and you want to take a break and try something else. 

So, after much thought over Antichamber, I finally have come to identify the 2 main elements that ultimately kill my interest in it. The first is the use of matter guns and how they're used to solve puzzles. After you've made a decent amount of progress at the beginning of the game, you're given the first of several matter guns which you can use to manipulate the environment in various ways, and this is necessary to solve puzzles. Also, there are several areas with translucent "fields" that you can walk through but will disintegrate all of the matter stored in your gun. Restarting a puzzle via quick-travel seemingly resets in that area the available matter needed to complete the puzzle and advance, but you can also, during normal play, organically wander across and gather additional matter that can make solving problem areas easier. Should you wander into a disintegration field or restart an area, you've lost all of that extra matter, and when attempting puzzles that seem difficult enough with the additional help of the matter, losing it and finding that you have to try again without the extra matter can be off-putting. (It's also worth noting that almost all matter in the game world can be recovered, but it usually takes a healthy amount of backtracking.)

Finally, the second thing that was a negative aspect to me was the implementation of a hard 90-minute timer. It's not unheard of for a puzzle game to have a time limit, but it feels really unnecessary here. Antichamber is not a very action-heavy title, and I really enjoyed observing the world around me and appreciating the visuals in the game, but I felt like I shouldn't because I was losing time meant for solving puzzles. Perhaps it would've made more sense had I advanced to a certain part of the game, but in my experience, it just felt like an odd design choice.

I do want to again stress that my opinion of Antichamber is only formed by how far I got into the game, and I know that I probably wasn't even half-way done. However, I feel that it says even more if a game entertains a player so little that they don't want to finish it as opposed to the same player completing it and deciding that it was a bad experience.

Question everything, backtrack, change your point of view, and get confused as hell.

129914079.review: Antichamber is a deceptively simple puzzle game with a series of short-form surreal puzzles in an ever expanding network of (anti) chambers. This game, I believe, has accomplished very effectively the art of keeping the mechanics simple on the surface level, but exploring them in interesting ways and with a lot of depth. The 3D space of video games allows for a TON of mind-blowing and unique puzzle potential-- this game seems to just scratch the surface of what's possible here. I think that this game was just as long as it needed to be, the puzzles are just difficult enough (and the almost metroidvania-style progression allows for a lot of flexibility), all combining to make a solid experience worthy of a follow-up. If you're into games like Superliminal, or any video game with puzzle elements, I heartily recommend Antichamber. 8.0/10.

128939136.review:
I had to edit this review because it turns out the way the game works is even less interesting than I gave it credit for.

Antichamber is a game where you wander around aimlessly through painfully garish hallways looking for simple puzzles to unlock cube guns, which will in turn allow you to solve other simple puzzles you may or may not remember coming across during your aimless wandering. Your aimless wandering will, for a mercy, put checkpoints on your map so you can return to various areas you've been when you are equipped with the right cube gun to solve their particular puzzles. The map and warp system cuts down on the wandering almost but not quite enough to make the game worth playing. Almost, because this game does not respect your time, and there are far too many dead ends or places where it loops pointlessly back to the beginning or elsewhere, accompanied by attempts at little life affirming messages which range from obnoxious to pretentious.

Unfortunately, the puzzles are not interesting enough to offset the aimless wandering, and the much lauded "non-Euclidean environments" are accomplished using a variety of cheap tricks in regular Euclidean space, like just warping you around and hoping you won't notice. People are apparently very impressed by these cheap tricks, but they are in no way ground-breaking.

Antichamber thinks it is way smarter than it actually is, and appears to have fooled a great many people, but it's just baby's first puzzle game wrapped in third-rate magic tricks, and sadly, it's too boring to even finish.

128672509.review:
[h2]What Are You Waiting For?[/h2]
Antichamber is a gaming staple. Nothing else! 
From the amazing concepts and their creativity, to the eerie soundtrack and quickly recognizable environments, this game features high replayability while being perfect for one sitting, too.

Check my [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m0Kej4MFOqY] gameplay [/url] and subscribe!

If you're wondering whether you should play this or not, well... you obviously should! 
Whatever you'll do, I'll share some more thoughts below.

[h3]Complex Simplicity[/h3]
What you'll see is a puzzle game with straight to the point mechanics. What you'll feel is something different.
I've played Antichamber many times through the years, always coming back to it because I was (and still am) fascinated by its patterns, level design and overall concept. 

This game features visual tricks that change your perspective on the various rooms which you'll come across. 
I always admired the simplicity in its design, all while being practically complex in reality. How meshes dynamically change with your interactions and how you'll need to revisit most of the rooms you've already been to while adding more and more.

[h3]Sound Leads The Way[/h3]
When I think about Antichamber, I immediately think about birds, eerie ambiance, focused sounds, no narrative whatsoever. That is because it's so well made that it become instantly recognizable and likeable. 

From a sound design perspective, this is the kind of things I love seeing on games.

[h3]Powers[/h3]
Although it may resemble portal at first glance, with its weapon and all, Antichamber actually has a different mechanic. Your goal is to place cubes correctly, and managing your resources accordingly, in order to overcome the various obstacles you'll come across while playing. 

Obviously, placing cubes isn't the only mechanic present in the game. You'll learn how to modulate these cubes, in order to multiply or elongate shapes to solve various puzzle.

What I've appreciated the most is that it all started with a simple cube. And everything revolved around it, creating a consistent gameplay loop. 

[h2]Go Ahead[/h2]
I'd suggest experiencing Antichamber. 
If you've never seen it, I'm a bit jealous. I would really like to experience again something like this. 

Well, not that I haven't! Manifold Garden, although different, provides a similar surreal experience.
Other than that, even at full price, this game is worth it. I hope to see more of this developer sometime soon. 

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/bodolovsello/recommended/]More reviews here[/url]!
[url=https://www.youtube.com/@bottolo/videos]My YouTube channel[/url].

127796191.review:
Antichamber es un juego en primera persona muy original y surrealista, que resultará entretenido y sorprendente por momentos pero, a la larga, es posible que empiece a hacerse algo repetitivo.
Nos encontraremos en un laberinto de varios niveles del cual debemos escapar, pero nada es lo que parece. Veremos que hay paredes y techos que desaparecen a nuestro paso; armas que disparan y absorben cubos; pasillos que, al girar sobre nuestros pasos darán lugar a otros escenarios y toda una serie de habitaciones cambiantes y puzzles complicados que harán de nuestro avance una ardua tarea. Todo ello a pesar de la ausencia absoluta de enemigos. Estaremos solos.
Gráficamente es un título muy especial, porque a pesar de su estética simplista, la combinación de colores resulta muy acertada y da al entorno una apariencia muy original.
La banda sonora es aceptable. No se hace pesada pero tampoco resulta pegadiza. Agradable pero simple.
La jugabilidad es bastante buena en cuanto a los movimientos de nuestro personaje y a su simplicidad, pero quizás se hace algo complicado el llegar a controlar bien el disparo de cubos y el control de sus movimientos con nuestra pistola.
La dificultad es muy elevada por la ausencia de lógica en el mapeado, que hace aparecer paredes, desaparecer techos o suelos, modificar el entorno con solo mirarlo o un sin fin de dinámicas surrealistas que son difíciles de comprender y que poco tienen que ver con la intuición. Solo por ello, la durabilidad del título podría ser de cientos de horas, en especial si quieres obtener todos los posters que iremos encontrando en nuestro camino, y que nos obsequiarán con refranes existenciales. Para conseguirlos todos necesitarás de muchas horas de deambular por esos pasillos imposibles, o tirar de alguna guía que te haga la vida más fácil.
En definitiva, valoro mucho la originalidad del título y por eso le doy una nota alta, aunque en contraposición opino que dar vueltas por un laberinto solitario peleándose con dinámicas sin sentido, a la larga empieza a hacerse algo pesado.

NOTA: 7/10

125917005.review:
Had this thing sitting in my library for the better part of a decade after having attempted to beat it on more than one occasion. This weekend I finally felt like getting a bit non-euclidean. It's got some great puzzles for sure, and if you gel with the mechanics and the Escher style puzzles then I think this game will be right up your alley.

Having now finished the game, I think it has a few too many rough edges for me to recommend it. On multiple occasions, some of the puzzle mechanics like lasers would not activate on the first try, or some gun functions would seemingly break without reason. Given the ever-changing nature of the game's mechanics, this often lead me to believe I hadn't done the puzzle in the proper way, or wonder if it was the game glitching out.

Going forward, I'll intentionally be a bit vague just in case anyone reading this would still like to see the game for themselves:

On many of the puzzles, especially after getting the yellow matter gun, they can be easily cheesed. It would be understandable if there was a clear and intended order to complete the puzzles, that way the first time you run into that puzzle it's easy to design around the tools at your disposal. However, it happens even during end-game puzzles when the devs thoroughly know what mechanics you have access to. 

There are just so many ways to abuse the matter gun mechanics to bypass the puzzles entirely. This isn't even done in a difficult or obscure fashion either, it's done by using the tools with their intended functions in a puzzle that didn't account for it. This really took me out of the whole thing. Often, the puzzles do not respect your time, making you do repetitive tasks or crossing through the same areas multiple times. For some later puzzles, I'd see the intended method to solve a puzzle, then opt to cheese it to save myself time and repetitive effort. As a player, being incentivized to skip the main point of the game isn't a great feeling. 

Apart from that, many of the puzzles of the game are more about first impression trickery rather than logic. That's not to say it's bad, and on a first playthrough it's pretty novel to have your mind blown seeing the world bend and morph around you. But with the backtracking nature of the game, having to redo these segments to progress to new areas is once again a time sink, and with nothing new introduced to keep it fresh.

Overall, it's an interesting game with interesting mechanics, but I can't recommend a game with this many rough edges for the current asking price of $20. If you really want to play it, get it on sale

124912918.review:
I completed the game in one sitting, five hours fifty seven minutes. Would I recommend? Yes.

[b]things I liked[/b]
- how the world changes
- disconnected world space, loops that curve in on themselves, hallways in spaces that don't fit
- areas/views that change depending on which side you look at (separate sides on a cube, etc) 
- [spoiler]the mechanic to stare at a "port hole" to navigate through a doorway correctly, otherwise loop back[/spoiler]
- the "crazy bird" orb thing, and the multi story puzzle near the end of the game
- the "walk" near the crazy bird mechanic
- learning new world mechanic: [spoiler]don't jump on invisible floor[/spoiler]
- no damage / enemies
- some of the door-cube-laser puzzles were pretty good, but it was starting to get repetitive. 
- ambient animal/insect/nature noises

[b]things that were ehhh[/b]
- [spoiler]The close up inspect-to-teleport. The mechanic is interesting. Horizontal teleportation was ok. Vertical was annoying.[/spoiler]
- Some puzzles you can access early. You can spend a long time doing them "the wrong way" with precise timing and precise click setups. Lengthy setups. Watching a playthrough after I completed mine, it's now apparent you were supposed to solve some of those much later, with better tools. Some of those "wrong access" puzzles were very frustrating, but as far as I could tell at the time I was where I needed to be.
- [spoiler]the block "drag" mechanic and the red block "grow" mechanic would often not go/grow where I was trying to get them, but would usually work[/spoiler]
- I think it's partly a feature of the game that "what to do" is sort of ambiguous except for the marker back in the start room, but mostly the entire game I was never really sure what direction to go to progress. It was more like take a guess, and the guesses seemed to lead to something new for the most part. There were a few times I went back to earlier content and was able to achieve something new. There were many times I went back to earlier content and accomplished nothing.
- I think there were arrow hints (good) about what to do after you'd been somewhere a second time, but at least at one point I think the arrows mis directed you down a pit when it seemed like I was supposed to avoid that, so I stopped trusting them (bad)


[b]things I dislike[/b]
- being informed at the start "one hour and thirty minutes remaining"
- [spoiler]how the world changes suddenly by looking away and back, or how you turn around and everything is different. The disconnected space is a good idea, but too much loss of control of location is annoying.[/spoiler]
- forced camera angle, for how important it was to place a cube precisely
- trampoline elevator mechanic, I hate this in every game its in
- can't crouch, placing a cube at the wrong height blocks you (note: crouching would break most of the laser puzzles)
- the minecraft "lookdown, jump and place block" mechanic is required, but the block is 4 inches big, so you have to click a thousand times.
- having to "grow the garden" so many times, over and over
- the block removal force fields are artificial gate keeping to add length to the game
- walls that are not solid, with no indication they are not solid
- seemed like there were a lot of places to soft lock (laser-door puzzles), which was pretty annoying after getting some ways into a puzzle and having to start over

124032836.review:
A puzzle game that puts you through the loop of throwing you into incoherent chaos for you to slowly learn the rules of the chaos, growing stronger and more competent for it, before being engulfed in a new chaos. 

This is a game I really respect, sadly I have not finished it yet. You really feel like an outsider trying to find your way in an alien world. And you start restricted, lost and unsure. But as you progress you learn the identical blank white walls and where they lead. You see empty areas you have been and find them familiar, stumbling back through memories of your thought process piecing it all together. Only now in retrospect and with a greater understanding. 

A lot of this sounds like a metaphor for life and I think it was intended as such. The main landmark you get are these black illustrated signs, and on each of them you get some kitsch quote. None of them are that meaningful and on their own are vapid. But the charm of them is that they are familiar platitudes in an familiar world. Their vapidity is comforting when everything else is alien. They have meaning because of the context. It starts to feel like the voice of a distant friend. 

But obviously it's not a friend, it's the developer. This is the world they created, and these are the words they wrote. They created this uncomfortable world, and they also comfort you through it. I don't even count this as meta as you can find some of the development history of this game in the game. The comforting words and the uncomfortable world are not different entities, they are one and the same. 

And that's how you feel playing, in the limbo between familiar and unfamiliar, trust and fear, comfort and discomfort. This is the meaningless limbo the developer has created for you to explore. It's a nebula, a catalyst, or maybe an opportunity. The developer wants to show you something, but we are all on our own journeys. This is not a painting or a song with a static message. This is a video game where how you interact with it changes the experience you take. From that, the message changes as well. You are putting the last brushstrokes on an M.C. Escher painting, what message or meaning it holds is up to you. 

This is the art of video games, a painting only completed by each viewer. Each viewer and artist, each save file an artwork. And every game a gallery curated by the developer.

123987308.review:
From the sound design to the visual aesthetic, I think this game is one of those that don't really age. Sure, once you know the solutions to the puzzles you can say the game is pointless, but I'd argue there's a vibe here that transcends just this being a simple puzzle game. 

Maybe it's a case of depth by omission, but to me when I've replayed this game recently for a video, I was caught off guard by how much of a trip it was, even if I knew what I was doing and where I was going. The little messages that you get along the way and the overall attention to detail really shines through on repeat playthroughs.

It's certainly a great game to recommend if you enjoy first person puzzle games, but beyond that it's just a pretty unique experience I've seen many times attempted but never really repeated.

120796715.review:
An incredibly clever game that I had for a long time, but took quite a while to actually sit down and play. There isn't really a plot, you're just solving puzzles/overcoming obstacles as you try to make your way to the exit and finish the game. I found myself playing through nearly all the game in no time, though 100% completion of it isn't required in order to finish it and reach the actual ending.

The entire game world is very non-euclidean and surreal in style, and requires a lot of abstract, outside-the-box thinking. Personally I got the hang of it quickly. The spectacle is all in the gameplay- you have to be more clever than the game and try to learn how to play by its weird rules. Navigation is never in a straight line, and pathways open in close in the most unexpected places. Aside from the puzzle of navigation itself, most of the puzzles focus on using a gun to manipulate cubes in various ways, and although it's simple the mechanics of it feel satisfying and rewarding to test out. There are a lot of moments where it almost feels like you broke the game, but no, it's just working as intended.

It's also quite soothing. The sound designs of the game and its calm, background ambient noise give it quite a dreamlike feel. The game constantly gives you little pieces of advice that almost always are both good advice for life, and a hint to help you in your current puzzle, and you can freely leave a puzzle and go visit a different one at any time.

Not too long of a play, not too challenging but still highly engaging, with a simple and well done aesthetic. 10/10.

120707221.review:
A minimalist puzzler with some nice elements of exploration and self-discovery. This game gives you just enough information to get your bearings, but otherwise doesn't hold your hand. There is no plot to speak of, and the music/SFX are sparse and ambient, giving the whole game a dreamlike quality. While not frustratingly difficult, there are still some moments that can be quite brain-bending, but nothing that can't be overcome. My only minor complaint is that the red gun kind of ruins the puzzle aspect of the game; it's just way too powerful and doesn't add any particularly interesting mechanics to the game, but at least it's only meant for the endgame.

All in all, I enjoyed this game a lot.

120187325.review:
A game that is expressly designed to mess with your expectations. Nothing is as it seems and things change if you look away.   
It's a puzzle game that builds on observational skill, logic and 'out-of-box' thinking. Sometimes a bit of jumping and timing skill is required (which I personally did not quite like).  
Do yourself a favor and consume as little media as possible about this game and jump in as blind as you can.  
Pay close attention to what is happening around and sometimes take the hints on the wall very literally.  
You can expect around 6 - 10 hours of puzzling.  
Very much recommended.

120158557.review:
[b]An extremely rewarding first-person puzzle game.[/b]

Its simplistic art-style isn't just for show, it's used to help create certain illusions and other perceptive-bending level designs for both its puzzles and exploration. It's pretty gimmicky, and the appeal of it doesn't last very long as it just becomes a normal thing you use to get around.
The game's also got some bizarre ambiance sounds. Despite the entire game taking place in corridors, there are a wide variety of sounds that you don't really expect to hear here, like jungle sounds and crazy weather. It's somehow immersive.

The entire game is nothing but puzzles and some platforming, with the end-goal being to reach the exit door. The only other true goals in the game are finding the gun and gun upgrades, which almost always lead to the sudden realization of being able to go back and finally solving the puzzles you previously left alone.
It's an incredibly non-linear game when it comes to its exploration and puzzle-solving, so whatever solution you find for a puzzle that seems outrageous may actually be intended, whether it's the only solution for it or not.
The best part about the game is how often it retroactively teaches you its mechanics and even tricks you can do to solve puzzles you thought you couldn't solve before without actually telling you to.

Strongly recommended puzzle game, highly advised to avoid any form of help.

118846782.review: While I loved the Portal series and I'm no stranger to puzzle games, I found this to be rather mediocre after initially being quite excited to give it a try. I just found too many faults with the game that hampered my enjoyment of it and I ended up uninstalling 2/3 through because I realized I was playing for the sake of completion rather than actually having fun. The biggest fault that I have with the game is it wastes the players' time. While it seems open world, it's actually linear. You MUST get the blue gun, then the green gun, then the yellow gun, then the red gun. There's nothing that alludes to this so unfortunately you waste a good chunk of time figuring this out because there are multi-step puzzles that seem possible to solve only to figure out they aren't without the right color gun halfway through. Something that further adds to this element of wasted time is this game is equal parts memorization game as it is a puzzle game. It's kinda like playing hop-scotch blindfolded and when you get it wrong you have to start over and remember there was a pit there or you used too many blocks and don't have enough leftover to complete the last part of the puzzle to open the door at the end to open up another part of the map. Lastly, I ran into a few bugs that forced me to start over in the map room. After around 7hrs, I was just done. I've got a TON of games in my backlog. I don't have to waste my time playing games that don't value it. If you read some of the other negative comments, they seem to echo what I'm saying.

118828290.review:
I have to give my appreciation to this game that introduced me to these kinds of mind-bending puzzles. Most of the emphasis in these puzzles is in actually figuring out what the puzzles are rather than how to do them. This is because the game likes to take what we know about physical geometry and turn it inside out. The whole game takes place in a liminal space where rooms are both recursive and impossible. Most of the puzzles are rooted in introspection and general life lessons which you'll often find are literal answers to each puzzle or at least hints.

All in all, I really enjoyed this game, 7/10 from me. Definitely recommend to friends who actually enjoy puzzles.

118377848.review:
Great puzzles, great mechanics & mechanics introduction, great pace, messes with your brain. You're encouraged to try new things, even if they might not work. There is no (written) tutorial, you just have to figure it out. Some people might say that no tutorial is bad for a puzzle game, but I disagree (lots of reading drains many puzzle games). 

This game introduces small mechanics, or enhancements to mechanics throughout the game. Once you master one, you'll likely encounter a puzzle requiring the next one. If you are stuck on one puzzle, the world lets you roam freely from where you have unlocked, and teleport back to where you have been from a hub. 

There are no loading screens, ever. And there are no menus, at all. Not even an ESC menu! This along with the ambient sound makes it very immersive. (I almost always play my own music, but I didn't for this game because of how immersive it was)

Overall this game is 'great' and a 10/10 for anyone who is into puzzles, although I would say it will probably be hard.

118347365.review:
Excellent example of the potential of non-Euclidean geometries. While the visual appearance of the world remains generally very minimalist, its structural characteristics is what entices us to admire it. 

Also the puzzles are well done. I enjoyed the different mechanics implied by the cubes, and the numerous and diversified applications within the game. My main gripe would likely be the progression difficulty within the first 2 hours (before you get better equipment), as the game lets you explore a lot of places simultaneously and as such, it might be quite difficult to know where you are "supposed" to go next. In other words, you might be walking around aimlessly for quite a while not realising that one of the blocked corridors you deemed inaccessible for the moment is in fact possible to cross with a mechanic you didn't know you had. I had the most fun closer to the end when you get access to incredibly powerful tools with tons of potentials, which somehow don't even make the game trivial.

As a final note, I found one gamebreaking bug, where the game would let me spawn as much cubes as like (a feature that's intended) to a point where the game would quickly crash.

That being said, it's definitely worth it if only for its unique characteristics.
8/10

117701757.review:
A difficult, but satisfying puzzle game. It's not as straight-forward as most puzzle games which will lock you in a room with a finite toolkit, which you need to use to escape. This game is a maze of rooms, each with some mind-bending puzzles, but you can teleport between them at any time, leaving you open to bouncing from one puzzle to the next. However, some puzzles aren't solvable without a given tool, and in a couple of cases I managed to brute force my way past some puzzles I wasn't technically meant to beat without said tool, leading me into an even more confusing puzzle than before. 

So, I don't think there's any shame in looking up solutions to a given room if you find yourself getting stuck trying to solve puzzles which you don't even realize are unsolvable.  I think the best way to play is see how far you can get on your own, watch a walkthrough if you get stuck for too long, and as soon as they show a solution to one of the puzzles you're getting frustrated with, hop back into the game, continue where you left off and see how far you get before you get stuck again, and repeat.

116010189.review:
[b][i]Antichamber[/i] is all about thinking outside of the box, but the box is common sense.[/b]

Like exiting a room through a door and expecting it to still be there after immediately turning around, only to find a long-ass corridor that just materialised out of nowhere. Or following a passage that makes six right 90º turns one after the other without the path never crossing itself. Or throwing yourself down a whole into the same exact room with the same exact whole you just left.

Yeah, if you've heard of "forget everything you learned in college" get ready for "forget everything you learned in preschool". You know, small things like object permanence or basic human reasoning regarding three-dimensional spaces. We don't do any of that here.

Jokes aside, [i]Antichamber[/i] is one of the most fun and original puzzle games that currently exists, and the reason for that is because it is, fundamentally, an enigmatic trickster. It is constantly pulling your leg, making you stumble through your false assumptions on how the game works. It is once you abandon what seems "obvious" and instead try to explore and reach further, to understand the rules and therefore the true possibilities and limitations of the game, that you're able to see the poetic secret behind every puzzle's solution.

[i]Antichamber[/i] plays by its own rules. It's a magician that always has a new trick up his sleeve, looking at your confident glare and pulling a fat smirk as you're walking right into his trap. You already fell for the trick, you just don't know it yet. But every trick has a secret, and finding it is about stop looking at where the magician wants you to look, and search elsewhere.

[b][i]Antichamber[/i] is a masterpiece.[/b] One of the best puzzle games ever made, and if you're remotely interested in the genre you'll do yourself a favor by letting it show you the incredibly ingenious, yet complicated riddles it has to offer.

This is one of those games that really blows me away. It reminded me of Manifold Garden in some ways (especially at the end), but more straight forward. I love puzzle games, and while this one was very simple in many ways, within it's simplicity are some difficult challenges.

The game sucked me in immediately and I found myself making good progress; but then hit a wall. Hard. I spent hours exploring, and while I would find new rooms or connections, I could not find what I know I needed to progress. I could see it, from two different areas, but just couldn't get there. I even found most of the next steps that I would need to take to make a lot of progress, I understood the future gimmicks, but I just couldn't get what I needed to progress.

However, by exploring for a long time, and trying far-fetched solutions which were definitely not intended (though some worked!) I stumbled across a concept in the game that I was missing. Something I really don't know how I missed, yet was extremely important. This concept was sort of explained, but I thought it was a part of game mechanics I could not control. A little frustrating, but I'm glad I chose not to look up the solution. With this concept in my toolkit, I was able to blow through most of the rest of the game fairly quickly.

I appreciated that there are multiple solutions to each puzzle. I found many as I was trying to narrow down how to progress towards the end (while stuck). By the time I got to the end, I had 100% the game without really having to try. I just had to get stuck for a while apparently lol. If you like puzzle games, this game is definitely worth it. I'm not the type of person to never use a guide, and sometimes I will to get some hints to get me unstuck, but I'm glad for this one I did not.

I got 16 hours out of this game and I found it to be totally worth the asking price. if it's on sale, it's a no-brainer.

Antichamber is one of those games that can make a gamer feel like an art snob.

It's probably the most abstract video game I've ever played. You find yourself in an escheresque series of blank white hallways and chambers that don't make sense by the rules of our world, but do conform to their own internal logic.  When you encounter a strange obstacle, that strange obstacle will always behave the same way.

The game makes use of its strange, non-euclidean structure basically as a series of fables, commenting on the nature of life.

It's not a particularly long experience and I didn't find it really worth replaying, but it's definitely an experience that's worth a look.

113844742.review:
[i]Originally posted on [url=http://www.dragon-quill.net/christmas-steam-games-2020-quickrecs/]Dragon Quill.[/url] Comments are enabled there.[/i]

This is basically what I was expecting Disoriented to be. It’s a first-person puzzler that feels like an acid trip. Rooms don’t logically connect up with each other, areas change depending on what direction you look at them from, and illusory floors and walls are everywhere. Crucially, though, unlike Disoriented it fills the space with interesting aesthetics and mechanics. Though the beginning rooms are in stark black and white, the environment ends up a kaleidoscope of shifting colors filled with bizarre and fascinating objects. A lot of puzzle games claim to be “mind-bending”, but this is the first time I’ve felt that was really accurate.

The central mechanic is that you have a “gun” that can absorb and place little cubes scattered throughout the environment; you can use them to wedge doors open, make steps or bridges, and a few other things. Unfortunately, this interacts with 3D really badly, since your cursor can only move in two dimensions. It’s impossible to place a block anywhere but adjacent to another surface, since the cursor will snap to the farthest point it’s directed at. This makes several puzzles much more frustrating than they need to be, [i]especially[/i] the ones about using blocks as elevators. First-person platforming is terrible, stop doing it!

The other issue is that — well, in Toki Tori 2, there are no hard barriers, and you’re limited only by your knowledge. That’s not the case here. Your gun gets several upgrades with additional abilities necessary to solve certain puzzles, meaning that it is possible to run into puzzles you literally can’t solve with your current equipment. This is a problem: because puzzles are supposed to be non-obvious anyway, it’s not immediately obvious whether you’re missing the tools you need or if you’re just not looking at it the right way. This leads to the frustrating side of Metroidvanias where you run in circles for ages not certain how to progress.

Despite that, once the game gets rolling it is very fun. The puzzles were genuinely clever and inventive, and though the mechanics are strange they [i]are[/i] consistent, and it is possible to learn them over time — crucial for any puzzle game. It gave me the sense of exploring an alien world and slowly piecing together how everything worked.

112461106.review:
Antichamber. The game that made my brain go form healthy to abc. It's certainly an experience and you should try it.

Antichamber is a first-person "shooter" (I hesitate to call it that) where you solve puzzles using a gun which allows you to move blocks around. The main appeal of the game, for me at least, is the confusion it brings. The world morphs around you in ways that hurt your brain. From this point onwards, I'll be talking about different parts of the game. You should play it blind for the best experience.

There are times where you walk down a hallway, find two stairs, come back to that hallway, only to realise it's now a new green hallway. Maybe then you walk into a room, see a window and look through to see a blue room. Turns out, you're now in that blue room. It's hard to explain, but it will melt your brain. However, that isn't the biggest reason why I like Antichamber. It's because of speedruns.

The fastest I've completed Antichamber in was 8 minutes. It feels amazing to have memorised all of the routes and confusing things, and it's an easy game to speedrun if you put a bit of practice in.

The story of the game is kind of like a life-lesson as you are told this guy's story. Collect all the pictures, figure out what happened. Stuff like that. You're taught morals along the way, which is certainly what I needed after my brain had been melted. The graphics are simplistic and not distracting as well, which helps.

All in all while I didn't write much for this review, it's because I can't explain this game. The best thing you can do is pick it up and play it for yourself.
Gameplay: 9/10
Story: 7.5/10
Music: NA (From what I can tell, there was little to no music in the game)
Graphics: 8/10
Final Score: 8/10 (Excellent)

112458599.review: A fascinating experience in puzzle solving, thinking differently, and questioning everything. An absolutely wonderful game for both people who enjoy both traditional puzzle games and something much more abstract. It can definitely be the kind of game that's beneficial to step away from for a while instead of trying to get through everything in one go; often a fresh perspective can give new insights. There's a lot to take in, and Antichamber truly feels crafted with a great deal of love and care -- it is the style of puzzle that almost [i]yearns[/i] to be solved while at the same time never going easy on you or giving you a simple solution as a "feel-good" reward.

112014363.review: i really enjoyed antichamber. it was a lot of fun. i'm not drooling over it like so many other people, nor did i believe it to be quite as mind bending as many say, though it is an interesting experience that's being given deserved praise. the game takes place in some sort of bizarre little world of hallways that works by different rules to our own universe's. this is what makes the game so interesting. the game is confusing and bizarre, particularly at the start, but it does work off a set of rules that by the end of the game you will likely feel somewhat comfortable with. it's almost explicitly stated that antichamber is about life, with the creator dropping little truth bombs or red pills or whathaveyou via signs after every puzzle. it starts out difficult and mysterious, and by the end, while still mysterious, you are functionally managing and navigating the world. there are many many different ways to beat this game, though they all end the same way. the paths branch, but they all end in what is presumably representative of death (meeting the black cube one last time and leaving the antichamber, a room before a larger room). the puzzles in this game shine when they don't involve using the matter gun. simply navigating the world of antichamber is a blast. moving around little cubes is tedious and boring at worst and just sort of unengaging at best. overall, i have surprisingly little to say about antichamber other than it's really fun and creative at times.

110569802.review:
TLDR Interesting experience if you can play normally with a QWERTY keyboard (WASD style) and use a normal mouse with a middle click. If you don't adhere to this, you won't have a good time. And In my case, the game can not be completed. 

The concept and the exploring aspect of this Antichamber is a pretty fun and unique one. The glaring downside is the options are so incredibly bare, and the lack of hotkey mapping makes the game impossible, in some cases. In my case, I have no middle-click on my 'mouse'. There was a guide to change hotkeys through config files, but that didn't even work for me. I'm an ESDF player, with an unconventional keyboard, with no normal mouse. 

As I mentioned in the TLDR, if you play WASD have a normal mouse with a middle click, you might have fun with this. 

The game is a first person platform-like puzzle exploration game. You wander through the facility following signs that have 'cryptic words of wisdom' on them. Things akin to "Some times rushing a solution is not the best choice." or "If you look at a problem long enough a solution will reveal itself." Which makes some interesting story telling and makes you want to really try to figure out all the puzzles, and even explore the nooks and crannies you run around.

I found no way to "exit" the game when I kept trying to edit keybindings in the configs. I had to alt-tab and "end task" from task manager. So take that with a grain of salt, or just chalk it up to my incompetence.
I would have loved to try and finish the game, but sadly, no keybindings means it's not possible for me, otherwise I would normally recommend this game to others.

Your mileage may vary. Hope my thoughts help. Thanks for reading.
