109674788.review:
I found this game in the 'similar games' section of Manifold Garden. While I was still completely in love with that game, I wanted to try something else. I can safely say Antichamber is now one of my favorite games. The puzzles were perfectly designed: challenging, sometimes not the most intuitive, but I never needed to look up a walkthrough, and none of the puzzles are frustratingly difficult. Unlike Manifold Garden, which is a very heavy on atmosphere, this game focuses much more on the puzzle aspect. I will say however, that the asthetic of the game, such as the little signs spaced throughout the map, are really pleasant and nice.
The ending was a perfect mix of surreal, confusing, and completely left field, but still had me feeling like I had completed something, which is often lacking in puzzle games in this similar vein.

Overall, Antichamber is a 9.8/10 game. The only thing that is missing from the game is more, which isn't really a complaint, but I digress. Even If you aren't the biggest puzzle game fan, I highly recommend this game. It will be worth it.
-Mirran

108793480.review:
Whilst this might be classified as a puzzle game, I see this more as a visual and perception smorgasbord with the puzzles tying together the gameplay loop itself. The most interesting parts of the game are where you get ping-ponged from one mind-bending room to another and responding to this craziness through your own approaches to puzzles, and it is thoroughly entertaining. 

The biggest issue about this game is how some areas have conflicting pacing that end up in you backtracking for way too long only to find that your tedious quest is met with a dev room [i] (Note: the dev rooms give a great insight into the development and I enjoy development-related secrets, but it feels disheartening when an incredibly obscure puzzle only leads you to a vague flow chart). [/i]

For a game so visually reliant, it's great that its artstyle compliments the gameplay and now has become so unparalleled. I remember seeing clips of this game when this came out and when I found this game again, I immediately recognised it and bought it solely from how its visuals stuck with my consciousness for so long. Although, it can get pretty overwhelming at times and I can understand if this game makes you ill.

Overall, this is a good experience that will surely challenge what our small Euclidean brains can comprehend, but the puzzles can get pretty annoying and guide-reliant by the end. Just approach this title as an exploration game with small puzzle roadblocks and you'll be in for a treat.

I feel really bad about giving this a bad review, because I think it's a great game - or parts of it, anyway.

First of all, the game is eight years old now. It doesn't run on all modern systems and on my end a windows update completely broke it.

Secondly, the first third of the game is the best part. As the game goes on, the puzzles become more about precision and less about experimentation, and it makes the game more of a drag. 105105786.review:
Gameplay: This game presents some great ideas, with some fun puzzling in a non-euclidean world. Just because you've already run down a corridor and it has led nowhere, doesn't mean you can't then walk down the same corridor and have something else happen, or jump down the same corridor and have a different thing happen, or walk backwards down the corridor and have another thing happen. However, this does become rather tedious as the world expands and you start to find more and more dead ends. You come to a corridor, and think to yourself, "have I already run down here, walked down here, jumped down here, walked down here backwards? Have I walked to that corner, then turned around and tried all of these separate things? I got to a point where I had approximately 30 different chambers, and after another half hour of getting nowhere decided to call it quits. Call it a lack of patience if you wish, but as something of an achievement hunter I have spent inordinate amounts of time on single achievements, so I don't think it's that. I just don't have any drive to discover the next door I can get through or platform I can open, because it simply means that the number of rooms I need to mindlessly explore has increased. Normally, I might use a guide if I was stuck on a particularly challenging puzzle in a game, but this doesn't drive me to want to want to get to the next stage.

Story/Content: I didn't see much in the way of a story from my brief gameplay. You're in a room, trying to get into another room, and then into another one etc. The little snippets of wisdom were fun and allowed you to reflect on your solution to each puzzle as you got through it. Some were particularly relevant to what you'd just encountered, some more tangential.

Music: The music is what you might expect for this game - a slow paced, ethereal sounding track that you don't really notice unless you're listening out for it. The rest of the sounds are made by the player/environment. They fit the ambience well even if the sounds are a little annoying at times.

Graphics/Visual: Visually, the game is designed to be out there. It has a blocky feel to it which is intentional, and feels fairly retro in that aspect when coupled with the vibrant colours. That being said, I did not enjoy the bright white, and had to turn the brightness of my screen down considerably to avoid my eyes hurting (and then back up again in the rooms where it was very dark).

I would say, if this is on sale for cheap, give it a go. I certainly wouldn't recommend it at recommended retail price.

“The most tenacious, infuriating obstacle you’ll face throughout the game is yourself.”
– PC Gamer
No, it's the endless running around in circles going through rooms trying to find what you've missed.

104048474.review:
Love this game so much!

It's a huge mind-f*ck. Makes you feel like a complete moron and the biggest genious, like a great puzzle game should.

I'll try to decribe it without spoilers as best I can but if you are super spoiler sensitive I'm going to just say it's probably a game for you (and what are you even doing reading reviews anyway?). Might sound weird, but I think that if you are here because you are curious about this game (i.e. likes first person puzzle games) and also very sensitive to spoilers about puzzle games, then you'll like this one.

It has a weird sense of progress. Not weird as in "bad" necessarily, but weird. There's the conventional progress towards the end goal, and then there is the completionist progress. Which, so far, not that weird. But it's a game where the end goal is not super clear, so you probably need to care about the completionist bit at least some to enjoy it properly. If you are the type of person who get's frustrated when you solve a puzzle and it turns out that you are not directly closer to the end goal, you might hate this game.
I want to make clear that it's very well designed though. As a puzzle game. It's not that there are all these dead ends that are only good for the completionist, added on top of the route to the end goal to just flesh out the game. No, all the puzzles still have a purpose to get to the end goal. You just don't always realize *how* right away when you solve them. But solving a puzzle almost always feels like learning something new about the game. There is a huge amount of "Oooh! I can do like *this*" and "So *that's* how it works!" -feelings when playing this game. Solving a puzzle will almost always either get you "physically" closer to the end goal, or it will teach you something new about the rules of this world that you need to know to krack the other puzzles that does get you closer to the end goal. Or both. There's a lot of both.
And sometimes you will not realise that you made progress until much later.
It's weird. It's amazing.
I wrote an essay about this game for school so I could go on about it for a while, lol. I'm not going to.

One thing to note if you are interested to buy it:
If you are sensitive to motion sickness from playing first person games, this might not be your game unfortunately.
You can always buy it and see if it works for you and refund it if you don't. But I would say it has above average motion sickness risk :\ I don't usually have problem with that at all and I sometimes had to take breaks while playing this because I got a little dizzy.
(It could also be that I would have felt that way after playing any first person game for 5 hours straigh and I just loved this game so much that I often played for longer sessions than usual without tiring... not ruling that out ^^')

Anyway!
Great Game!

102507610.review:
First few minutes are spent walking through a corridor, realizing you've been there before, turning back and realizing that the place you came from is no longer there. Once the novelty of this has worn off, Antichamber is basically a normal puzzle game. Which is not a bad thing, there are some satisfying puzzles to solve, but it's not as "psychological" or "brain-frying" as some reviews might lead you to believe.

Once you've gotten used to Antichamber playing some 3D space warping tricks on you, you can start to focus on the puzzles. The puzzles in this game mainly involve the Brick Gun, which is capable of picking up, storing and manipulating small bricks you find throughout the maze. You progress through the game by finding upgrades to this gun, eventually getting one that has the abilities to unblock the exit. In your way of getting these upgrades are several puzzles involving bricks which can be manipulated by the Brick Gun.

There are more things to find than just the exit though. The most common thing are signs which tells you something profound about life. At times I personally found these a little pretentious, but the way they usually parallell the things you did to find them made them entertaining most of the time.

There are also rare purple blocks which are way more hidden than anything else in this game. I didn't feel the need to hunt down all of them.

If I can give one piece of advice that I felt the game should've told you about, is how to interpret the map.
In the Antechamber (no not a misspelling), which is where you begin and where you can go anytime by pressing ESC, there is a map of the whole maze. Large squares represent rooms in which you haven't found all the exits. Small squares represent rooms where you've found them all. Round "cul-de-sac"s are all dead ends. If you're stuck, check any rooms that are still large squares. Another piece of advice is to study the bricks you can manipulate with your Brick Gun. They have a few quirks that you need to make use of in order to progress through the maze.

Finding all the signs and the exit to the end took around 7 hours. It might take longer depending on how long you're stuck. For me I'd say 2-3 hours were spent being stuck.

If you like puzzles, give this game a go. Make sure to marvel at how many corridors lead to the room "Stairway to Heaven".
Seriously, that corridor is white like almost every other corridor in this game and you still just know that room is around the corner.

99424555.review:
Anitchamber does a really good job at marketing itself as a mind-bending game. It certainly feels unique.
But ultimately the game consists of mostly fairly poorly constructed puzzles, with semi-consistent "hidden" rules (that are not really hard to grasp, and so of low value). When you solve a puzzle it doesn't feel like an achievement - with the exception of a few rare cases, either the puzzle is trivial (when following strictly the rules of the game), or it's just trying "random" stuff that have no logic behind them.

While the game manages to give the sensation that puzzles require ingenuity that actually makes sense, it very rarely actually makes sense - the example in the trailer is one of the only cases where the game actually succeeds (the solution for that puzzle is both creative and actually the only logical solution - you know you're right when you think of it even before testing it). But it doesn't manage to maintain that same level in the rest of the game.

98990387.review:
Antichamber no tiene que ser considerado un juego, porque esa descripción no le hace justicia. Antichamber es una experiencia, y lamentablemente para nosotros, una experiencia muy corta pero que se quedara para siempre en uno.

No hay palabras claras como para describirlo ya que es tan confuso como fascinante. Pareceria que Antichamber es quien realmente juega con nuestros sentidos y lo que percibimos como "realidad", haciéndonos ver que no todo lo que vemos es el total de nuestro universo, si no, que solo es un poco de lo que nos rodea.

"¿Qué?", "¿cómo?", son algunas frases que seguramente repetiras a medida que avances en el extraño universo de Antichamber.

Si te gustan los juegos surrealistas, que juegan constantemente con la cuarta pared como Gorogoa, The Stanley Parable, Fotonica o Superliminal, este juego definitivamente te enamorará y confundirá.

98005581.review:
Do I recommend this? Yes.. But with a caveat. That there may be some kind of bug that can corrupt your save and cause your progress to be lost. I appear to have had this happen, and several other people have complained of the same thing.
With that being said, after being mildly annoyed, I just restarted and have made a mental note to not leave ages between saves.
Gameplay is fun enough that I'm happy to repeat the experience (because I'm old and my memory is bad).

This is a science-based game for physics nerds that like to have their minds meddled with. 
You are initially walking around in a 3D space and the challenge is to navigate your way through an unconventional maze. 
Early on in the game, you pick up a gun that allows you to manipulate your environment.  Later on, other guns allow you to manipulate the environment in different ways.

Lateral thinking is frequently rewarded. Other times things are simpler than they might first seem, and stopping for a second can improve your capacity to comprehend. Puzzles are not as mind-breaking as, say, Myst, but can cause frustration in small amounts.

Graphics are sparse but have impact in their simplicity. Movement is simple but can be disorienting due to the sparsity of the graphics. Timing can also be difficult due to the lack of spatial clues in some areas.
Overall though, a really cleverly put together game that'll have everyone scratching their head during at least one part.

97997992.review:
Think "Portal" only you can't die, the gun fires and moves cubes instead of portals, and you have to do a lot more thinking outside of the box.

I've been playing video games since the early 90's and this is without a doubt one of the greatest video games I have ever played. There's really no story other than the fact that you're in a chamber and have to make your way through to the end. There are no tutorials other than telling you what your gun can now do whenever you obtain an upgrade, and there are cryptic hints as you go, and the ways to progress through the various chambers varies greatly from chamber to chamber. The game takes as long as it takes you to figure out the various chambers and how to solve them. It is challenging, beautiful, has great sound design, and must have had some of the smartest game developers in the industry working on it because it is truly an experience. It is very rewarding to complete and finally reach the exit.

97124768.review:
[u]Antichamber[/u] is a first person puzzle game similar to [u]Portal[/u], [u]The Talos Principle[/u], and [u]The Witness[/u]. It differs from those games mostly in its presentation and its physics.

Antichamber is not a pretty game. This is likely a combination of artistic style and budget constraints but you will be wandering the same white polygonal hallways over and over again with very little change in the scenery. This is function over form as this does make it very clear what objects you can interact and what you can't.

And this is very important in Antichamber because its hallmark feature is that physics in this game bare no resemblance to our own world. Rooms move and disappear merely by not looking at them anymore. Turn a corner and the place you were just at has disappear. Which is not to say the game has no logical consistency. It does try to explain the rules by which this world operates. But there are still many times you'll just stare quizzically wondering why the ground fell out from under you or a room just disappeared, as it'll often seem capricious. This makes exploring a massive pain as you simply don't know if you can backtrack or not, as very likely the room you came from was replaced by something else entirely.

With that preface out of the way, [u]Antichamber[/u] does have some good puzzles. You will eventually start manipulating cubes to create matter, build bridges, and solve jigsaw style mazes. Some of these are very satisfying, others less so. Its other big foible is that this is less self contained puzzles rooms than it is Metroidvania. You won't know for sure if a given puzzle solvable because you lack a specific item/upgrade. Like most Metroivanias there is some color-coding going on to help you know but this isn't always present. 

There is no story to speak off and sound design is passable. There is quite a lot of extra puzzles and Easter Eggs if you like what you see.

[u]Antichamber[/u] gets a marginal thumbs up. I would recommend it to anyone that likes these First person puzzle games, but absolutely not to anyone new to the genre as it will frustrate them beyond belief.

96662908.review: An interesting game with a lot of neat spatial tricks to keep your mind confused. I'm really here for the visuals, which I find vibrant and distinctive. The minimalist appearance of most of the map lends itself to this style of game because it effectively amplifies the intensity of any environmental stimuli or puzzle elements you encounter. The puzzle mechanics themselves are pretty straightforward, but you still have to think decently hard to get through the tougher ones. I also enjoyed the game's flexibility in allowing you to travel nearly anywhere you've been without taking a marathon-length trek in the interim. I'm not a fan of the countdown clock—I'd rather not be rushed, even if [spoiler]it ultimately doesn't affect the gameplay[/spoiler]. But all things considered, [i]Antichamber[/i] is an enjoyable game, and I recommend it.

One of my favourite puzzlers, though very hard to describe. It obviously has plenty of interesting non-euclidean structures, but it's appeal comes from the subtle ways it asks you to work through it's specific mechanics. Some things are a simple matter of learning how they work, while others require a new understanding of existing skills.

Although it can involve some backtracking and occasional frustration, and newer games have pulled off the non-euclidean style in a much more comprehensive way, Antichamber fills a special niche for me with its puzzles and exploration that no other game does.

96327691.review:
The first third of the game was neat.  But then, it got more and more obscure and intentionally obtuse.  Crucial gameplay mechanics were *not* introduced to the player *at all* - forcing me, and probably others, to seek out a walkthrough to get through a few of the more obscure puzzles.  Two mechanics used in those puzzles I would have *zero* clue about, as the game likes to use really smarmy "hur hur hur I'm so smart look at this vague hint about something you must have figured out by now" comments on the walls.  

At a certain point, if the game doesn't tell you how to play it, it's the game's fault - and that is the problem with this game.  At the end, I just wanted the game to end - and that "wanting the game to end" lasted me more time than my initial enjoyment of the game.  For some of the puzzles that I had to look up, even with the walkthrough, I'm *still* not even sure if the puzzle was solved correctly or did I get lucky somehow brute forcing my way through particular sections?  If the player isn't sure what the game mechanics are, then the game did a poor job of communicating that - and this is done throughout.

Comparing this game to Portal does a disservice to Portal.  Portal always provides the means to solve the puzzles through actual hints - this game simply says stuff like "you can make a garden anywhere" which, without knowing what the heck that's supposed to mean, is completely meaningless - and even though I know now, because again - *walkthroughs* - I still wouldn't know what that meant if it was just me stumbling around [spoiler] you can make blocks if you do blocks of them and let them be filled in, but I didn't even know that was a mechanic! I didn't know why blocks would fill themselves in, it seemed completely random to me and I just went through them if I could! There's another mechanic that is also not explained, but I'll leave that to you with the walkthrough - because it's *also* not explained....[/spoiler]

The beginning is strong, but the gameplay becomes near unbearable as you continue - 5/10, would not recommend.

95567225.review: Now you're thinkin' with Antichambers! This non-linear first person puzzler subverts traditional puzzle games by requiring out of the box thinking to navigate surreal non-Euclidian obstacles. Instead of relying on increasingly complex mechanics of a single dimension, like Portal's Portal Gun, Antichamber constantly requires you to break its own rules. The best puzzles in Antichamber leave you questioning if you solved the puzzle "correctly" or found some unintended workaround. Crisp lines, popping colors, and an ambient soundtrack combine with clever puzzling to make this game a unique must-play: 10/10. A little spendy for 2-10 hours of game so maybe try to get it on sale.

94583217.review:
Most 3D puzzle games like the Portal series teach you new mechanics as you progress further, and they require you use those mechanics in synergy to solve the puzzles. This game does that to a degree, but it mostly forces you to stretch your creativity muscle and come up with new ways to solve the puzzles yourself. That is a very important distinction, and it makes Antichamber quite unlike any other 3D puzzle game out there.

As you've already seen from the screenshots on the store page, the game's visuals mostly consist of solid colours splashed onto featureless white rooms. This serves an important purpose, because the game contains a lot of instances of non-Euclidean geometry. Examples include hallways that end at the exact same point that you walked in and hallways that go right through each other yet don't actually seem to intersect. The visuals are built around the purpose of orienting you in this strange world.

The soundtrack is soothing, aids in concentration and doesn't distract you from the puzzles at all. More impressive is the way sounds of nature are sprinkled throughout the puzzles. Moving particles often sound like birds flapping their wings, landing on the ground after falling from a great height sounds like splashing into a pool of water while the game doesn't actually contain any sort of liquid anywhere, and sounds you'd normally hear in a rainforest form a subtle hint to move towards areas decked in green.

All of these elements in amalgamation create a unique, surreal atmosphere that makes the entire game feel like a very abstract dream. Antichamber will stay in your mind long after you've finished it, and you might find yourself coming back to it now and then.

Going through this game blind is, in my opinion, the main prerequisite to experience its brilliance in full. Unfortunately I spoiled myself with some parts of the game, and it made my adventure not as mindblowing as it probably could've been. Don't make the same mistake I did. If you have even the slightest interest of buying the game, then don't ruin the experience for yourself and play through it without knowing anything.

94170068.review: Antichamber delights and confuses players, but is absolutely fair as far as a puzzle game is concerned. Where it falls short, however, is the at times non intuitive mechanics with the matter guns as well as a lack of indication to players that a room is just a room and sometimes that room is simply from the Devs. Puzzles felt smooth and doable and once you figured them out, there was certainly a satisfying "aha!" moment to revel in. That being said, I would have liked to see a bit more direction or indication where Dev rooms existed as I was literally stuck in one for a good chunk of time thinking I had a puzzle in front of me to solve (here's looking at you "Over the Edge"). Additionally,  controls for the matter guns could be frustrating for some of the longer puzzles. One instance that comes to mind is dragging blocks where you want them in a puzzle where the null barriers exist. Sometimes, you would misplace your end point and cause your entire block formation to march to their inevitable suicide into the unflinching conflagration that those barriers act as. As well, with the red matter gun, the default flow of blocks appears naturally vertical in nature. You can make a horizontal flow but at a very specific angle and setup and again, this is not intuitive to the player. Finally, being unable to capture this game in a full screen window was a minor annoyance, but not a deal breaker. It's surprising to stumble across a game that can't do that these days. All in all, if you are a fan of games like Portal or Myst where spacial puzzle solving is a sure thing to block your progress, this game is for you. 7/10.

93010453.review:
What I look for in a game like this is puzzles that make me think outside the box while being logical enough that they can be solved by reasoning things through, or possibly with a *little* experimentation. What I WANT is to put the powers of my mind into practice, and enjoy working towards epiphanies; what I DON'T want is to spend my time guessing at solutions that feel random, or trying ever more ridiculous alternatives because the correct solution, when I first try it out, doesn't seem to be panning out. In my opinion, the ideal solution shouldn't be obvious at first, but SHOULD FEEL obvious once you've figured it out.

I try not to look up solutions, but if I start to suspect that I've run into a game design issue, I'll eventually hit the wiki, and usually when I do that I feel it was the right decision. I made it through Braid and maybe Portal without help from outside the game, so I really appreciate how they made me think without setting me up to waste my time guessing at what exactly the devs wanted from me.

I'm not sure what kind of a game Antichamber wants to be. Most of the puzzles make you think to some degree, and that can be a lot of fun, but others merely ask you to reuse simple mechanics that you've already mastered, and still others are pretty random. For one of the game mechanics, there's no logic to it, you just have to try different things until you discover what the devs want you to do with it, and for a long while it's not clear that they want you to do anything at all. The map that shows you where you've been and which rooms you've solved is confusing, and when you're in the rooms, it's difficult to tell which colored walls are supposed to be interacted with and which just happen to be colored.

I have a feeling that the devs wanted this to be a psychologically or spiritually educational experience, and that this explains why so many of the puzzles are designed to "waste" your time -- to help you learn the value of being persistent and attentive in real life, and of not being discouraged when some paths are a dead end, stuff like that. The game has a lot of posters with different life tips that are connected to the puzzles, like "Patience can be rewarding" and "If both paths go to the same place, it doesn't matter which you choose." One room in particular, the trick is simply to keep doing the same thing over and over until, long past the point of reason, it starts to work for you. One particularly revealing poster: "The more you've explored, the harder it is to find what you've missed." In other words, "Welcome to the walking simulator part of this game." So it seems that most of the game-design "flaws" were inserted on purpose, to make you think about the limitations of puzzle-solving in real life, to prepare you to think as a person who has to make their way in a world that's often confusing and can't always be gamed.

How do I feel about this? I do appreciate the attempt to undermine what I call "the gaming mindset" -- "Someone has told me I can 'win' by doing XYZ, so I'll spend dozens of hours trying to do just that, for no other reason than to hear someone tell me I succeeded." I'm glad they tried to offer something better than that. At the same time, I don't appreciate that this involves me running around to different rooms for thirty minutes at a time trying to figure out what exactly still needs doing and whether I can even do it yet. That's not a real alternative to the gaming mindset -- from one angle, it's a distillation of it: I'll keep doing XYZ, not because I enjoy it, but because I have to do it to "progress."

This wouldn't be the case if I really felt I learned something new and precious from this game. I'm fine with being bored and frustrated for a while if I get something greater out of it, even in a game. But I already have the rest of my life to drill these lessons into me through personal experience. When I fire up a game on a Friday night, I've spent 40+ hours that week working as a cog in the corporate machine, reviewing documents for ultimately insignificant errors, and "collaborating" on projects and meetings that will have to be undone the next week with more projects and more meetings. If I'm going to play a game that wants to teach me something about that sort of experience, I'd like it to teach me without submitting me to EVEN MORE of that experience. At least, it should warn me at the start what kind of game it is, in no uncertain terms. That way I can devote my leisure time to activities I actually like, and if I suspect that I need a little more practice with patience, I'll know just where to go.

Ultimately, I stopped playing just before the end of the game. Couldn't convince myself that it was worth another minute of my time. For me, escaping the "gaming mindset" with Antichamber meant putting the game down. That's particularly unfortunate because it's pretty obvious that it was made by clever and thoughtful people.

90058137.review: Puzzle games appeal to me.. But I was never really attracted to Myst or The Room.. Anti-chamber is a game where the sum of it's parts make it something more.. It's why great art becomes more than just a set of brush strokes and techniques. While mechanically and visually this game ticks all the boxes; it's the experience of challenging your own thinking, learning abstract ideas and being rewarded for doing so that makes this game great. Anyone can add together the best elements of a game, but when summed together, they don't achieve greatness unless the ideas that brought them all together (the user experience, not just the interaction experience) has followed a vision and been masterfully crafted towards that vision. I loved what this game gave to me and am really thankful that someone went to the effort of making it. It was hard and frustrating at times. But I could think about it while being away from the game, leave it for a long period, and then come back with fresh eyes and often move forward. I think if this game kept going forever, I would play it forever. I've been gaming for 32 years and this gave me something new and one of my best gaming experiences. At first you might just see abstract and nonsensical mechanics, but stick with it and start to understand it and you get a rewarding payoff. Excellent work 10/10. Make another game you genius designer.

Covered in worthless platitudes serving as a pitiful excuse for philosophical depth. I found more value laughing at them. 

No pause menu. Don't accidentally hit esc when you get up to get a drink. The game will undo your progress. Want to turn the music off? Hit esc and lose your progress. Not much progress but still annoying. I guess this dev wanted to pioneer a new vision for the video game menu. 

Inclusion of impossible architecture for... reasons, I guess. It only serves to jar your sense of direction. The puzzles that actually use impossible architecture are just junk filler puzzles. It's less of a mechanic and more of a style or theme. 

Some of the puzzle are poorly communicated. As in, was there a puzzle I was suppose to do before this one? Did I complete the puzzle or not? Is this even a puzzle? What happened now that I completed this puzzle? It could have been done so much better. 

Overall, pretty easy for a puzzle game. If you're looking for a puzzle game to work through, meh, there's a few thinkers in here. Although I'm pretty sure I skipped the "tutorial" puzzles for one of the mechanics. So who knows, maybe it's even easier than I thought it was! I'm serious though, I have no idea what these people are talking about when they say it's hard. I would say A Monster's Expedition is a tad harder than Antichamber. Baba Is You, The Witness and Infinifactory are miles ahead of this game in difficulty. I'm afraid of Stephen's Sausage Roll but I breezed through this game. It's not hard.

86908336.review:
Antichamber is a non-euclidean puzzle game. It is based largely around using a "brick gun" and using it to place and manipulate different-colored bricks. It heavily rewards exploration and experimentation—so heavily that it doesn't actually reward them but rather it requires them both in copious amounts. It is not for everyone: the garish, abstract graphics and topological spaces will make some peoples' heads spin.

What I like about Antichamber is that it's utterly unique. The only thing I've seen that comes remotely close to capturing the essence of Antichamber in recent years is "There Is No Game" and its sequel, and even then, those games are vastly different because they're illogical, whereas Antichamber is logical. Antichamber makes [i]you[/i] into the puzzle. Like the trailer says, you are your own greatest obstable, and every aspect of the game is there to get you out of your comfort zone and challenge your presuppositions. Almost every puzzle has its own idea, and some of them make you feel like you’re breaking the rules.

What I don’t like about Antichamber is how stupid it makes me feel sometimes. But other times it makes me think my brain is too big to fit inside my skull.

I would recommend it to patient puzzle-lovers who aren’t sensitive to the graphics or the disorienting geometry. This game is like a seven-course dessert (at least for me): don’t consume it all at once. Take a bite, and when you’re full, walk away for a bit and come back for more later. Don’t look at hints unless you absolutely have to. You’ll ruin the fun. But you probably know that, already.

86248660.review:
Antichamber is an interesting puzzle game that challenges how you think about geometry. It makes heavy use of rooms with geometry that is seemingly impossible in the real world. This non-Euclidean style of gameplay makes for some interesting and fascinating puzzles that I thoroughly enjoyed. While great, I would have liked to see Antichamber make even more use of them. While some of the cube puzzles were really fun, others felt like they didn't have much or anything to do with the non-Euclidean geometry that made this game so fun. The gameplay is absolutely the core of Antichamber. If you won't enjoy non-Euclidean puzzles, you won't enjoy this game. If you are interested in this however, I think it is a wonderful experience.

The game has no plot beyond teasing you with the exit of whatever non-Euclidean complex you've found yourself in at various points. There is, however, signs. When interacted with, they provide vague hints for the various puzzles that double as life advice, which I felt was a neat touch.

The game's music is very well suited to the game. The tracks aren't distracting, fading into the background as you focus on puzzles. The game's music fits the ambience very well, though when removed from the context of the game it is not particularly noteworthy.

The simple graphics prevents visual distractions from the puzzles, and in my opinion is fairly enjoyable. However, many people have reported motion sickness from this game so if that affects you I would definitely keep that in mind.

Overall I found Antichamber a highly enjoyable and unique puzzle game. If the premise of the game interests you then I would recommend this game.

85305036.review:
[h1] A Serendipitous MINDF**K [/h1]
I watched a GDC video of Alexander Bruce, the creator, giving a talk on his long and grueling process while making Antichamber to the point where he nearly brought himself to tears. His incredible speech led me to buy this game and, by god, does his hard work show!

[b]Every room, every hallway, every turn[/b] completely throws off your perception, forcing you to recount your steps and even your thoughts. If you blink or turn your camera .00001 degrees you'll be sure to miss something. And even with this barrage of mindf**kery, Bruce does a fantastic job of balancing intrigue with stress. Never was I too overwhelmed with the complexity of a puzzle. This might be due to the fact that the soothing nature ambiance kept my spirits in check while my brain was melting. The encouraging checkpoint posters helped too:)

[b]Each puzzle is so refreshingly unique![/b] From infinite stair loops to spastic balls in your face, not only are these rooms aesthetically pleasing, their aesthetic almost always serves a purpose to solving them. There's meaning behind the trippiness!! I could write pages about my favorite experiences from these puzzles but I'll savor the moment if you haven't played this yet.

[b]The Guns... Oh, the guns.[/b] Obtaining these circular square-spitters was definitely the most difficult part for me but I'm sure this is by design. Each gun acquired simply adds one new mechanic to the puzzle-solving process but the field of possibilities that you come to realize when you finally acquire it will make you gitty like a kid on christmas. I enjoyed the feeling of unlocking a better gun and frantically running around the map to solve all the puzzles I was previously stuck on for hours. It was nice to know I wasn't just stupid.

[b]IN SUMMARY[/b]
Antichamber is a mesmerizing work of art that managed to make me feel so alone and yet so comfortable at the same time. 3/3.

Bravo, Mr. Bruce! Bravo.

[h1]SHOULD YOU BUY THIS GAME?[/h1]
[b]If you're a fan of puzzle games:[/b] You should've already bought it by now.
[b]If you're a casual gamer/not really into puzzles:[/b] Give it an hour of your time! You will not regret it!
[b]If you're an FPS fan:[/b] It has guns. You have to. That's your obligation.

85294666.review:
[b] Comentario Pre-Reseña [/b]:
Todo lo señalado en esta reseña no debe ser considerado como una verdad o mentira absoluta, múltiples factores pueden afectar al que muchos no estén de acuerdo con lo que voy a decir o puede que incluso dé a conocer cosas que realmente no son verdaderas.
Básicamente, tenga en consideración que:

-Puede que no interpretara correctamente el juego (ya sea historia o como se debía jugar)
-Factores que señale positivos o negativos están sujetos a opinión y preferencias, nunca objetividad.
-No me considero un experto, por lo que sugiero no dar mucho peso a lo que señale a continuación.

[i] Esta Reseña tiene la intención de no contener ningún spoiler para nuevos jugadores, dando detalle a hechos solo ocurridos entre los primero 5 [min] de juego. [/i]

Con todo lo anterior aclarado, te invito a continuar:

[h1] AntiChamber [/h1]

Un juego de Puzzles y desafíos mentales que intentara mantenerte atento para que no te pierdas en las extrañas reglas por las que se guía este lugar que estas recorriendo, con una meta relativamente clara; explorar y superar desafíos, tendrás que enfrentarte a tu propia mente y hacerte capaz de abrirla para asi aprender y entender todo lo que te rodea.

[h1] Apartados Considerados [/h1]

[b] Jugabilidad [/b]:

AntiChamber es un juego de primera persona y lo que mayormente estarás haciendo será recorrer el mapa y pensar, y mucho. Con controles simples de mirar objetos e intentar complenderlos junto a las mecánicas del juego sentradas en hacerté pensar, observar y aprender… poco se puede decir de este apartado para crear un gran peso. Pero si es por decir algo relevante, no pase un mal rato al caminar por todo el recinto de AntiChamber.

--------------

[b] Visual [/b]:

[i] Aunque este campo lo considero necesario, no soy bueno al momento de Juzgar correctamente este apartado [/i] (Téngalo presente)

La temática y diseño es tan simple como puede, superficies de colores planos y objetos completamente cúbicos en su mayoría te darán una experiencia visual muy comun, pero la magia aparece con los juegos mentales que estos simples pero engañosos entornos intentaran jugarte mientras recorres los pasillos, escaleras y otros lugares mas. No te dejes engañar por lo simple que todo se ve, esconden su belleza e interés en lo profundo de la mente.

--------------

[b] Historia [/b]:

Si es por referirse a una historia, con seguridad puedo decir que AntiChamber posee un final, posiblemente no habrá un desarrollo de personajes ni nada por el estilo, pero si tenemos un objetivo, que se nos presenta antes de jugar; el explorar todo lo que este juego nos quiere mostrar. Mientras mas tiempo pases en los pasillos, AntiChamber te guiara hacia nuevos objetivos, por lo que no temas, nunca perderas el norte. (Quizas si el camino… pero sabes a donde tienes que llegar)

--------------

[b] Dificultad [/b]:

Este no es un juego facil de catalogar en niveles de dificultad, pero no lo mostraria como algo fácil, pero a la vez tampoco difícil, es tan ambiguo como el juego mismo. La dificultad para superar los desafíos estará a la par con cuanto te niegues a ver lo que ocurre, algo que haras en los primeros minutos de juego inconscientemente. Si eres bueno pillando detalles, sin duda pasaras las pruebas, o al menos las descifraras con rapidez. Pero este juego lo catalogaría como una aventura, no te apresures en superar los desafíos, aprecia lo que vas aprendiendo, busca los desafíos, no por el querer terminar este juego, sino porque quieres ver que tienen para enseñarte.

--------------

[h1] Veredicto [/h1]

AntiChamber es un juego Hermoso, su apartado grafico es simple, pero es el como pinta en tu cabeza lógica y entendimiento lo hermoso. Siento que debe verse como una experiencia, no como un desafio, disfrutar de como te plantean los desafíos, tener que estar atento al mas mínimo detalle, son las cosas que le entregan una belleza muy curiosa a este juego. Pero algo importante, para este juego sin duda tienes que poseer paciencia, el bloquearte puede ser algo común en un juego de este estilo. Se consciente en lo que te metes, tendrás que usar bastante tu cabeza.

En resumen: un juego altamente recomendado, nunca esta mal entrenar la cabeza, mas aun cuando se trata de cosas que se escapan a nuestra lógica común y corriente. Y poco mas, tan simple como esto, pero expandido en otro transfondo. 
---------------

[i] Toda esta reseña está basada en el gameplay subido en el canal de Youtube a nombre de esta cuenta de Steam (No dejo link ya que considero que mi contenido es basura) [/i]

Muchas gracias por leer, espero, estimo y deseo que estén bien. Hasta Otra.

Trippy game that is short but amazingly unique and intriguing. I do recommend this game for players who like puzzle games in general, players who like experimental games or players who enjoy a challenge and hacking their brains to figure out what is going on.

84225707.review:
TL;DR: The game is amazing and you should absolutely buy it, one of the best puzzle games I have ever played, do not watch a guide.

One of the most unique puzzle games I have ever played. The visual style feels like you're on LSD (in a good way), the gameplay is amazing and rewarding creativity, the puzzles are logical and make you go "why didn't I think of this" and the various panels giving you tips serve more as setting you on the right track and never spoil the answer (quite the opposite even actually!). The progression is like a Metroidvania where some paths are blocked because you don't have the right upgrades which are very rewarding when you get the upgrade and a lot of paths open up. The only (kinda) negative thing is that in the middle to late game you can get stuck, but these moments rarely lasted more than 5 minutes (which is very low compared to other exploration-based games). The game is also a bit short but for the quality and the low price it's really not a problem, there are even a few secrets to find that give cool information about the game and it's creation. I did not 100% the game, I have finished the game having done a few side stuff and enjoyed the game a lot (I also have never touched a guide, which nobody should read as it spoils the whole experience)!

84005065.review:
I have played both Portals and Talos Principle and personally find the Antichamber to be the biggest challenge from all three. It's a beautiful example of hard dev work and a unique experience for sure. It might throw some people off because there is no standard tutorial. You have to find everything on your own. That said, it's not that big of a mindfuck as I thought it would be. There is still an elementary logic to your paths and they stay the same every time you take them.
Although I didn't have the patience to finish Talos Principle on my own (some secret puzzles relied on you finding the "needle in the haystack" solution, aka where to put your crystal staff) I tried to finish Antichamber with no help at all.
I did not succeed because, again, I did not have the patience but I would suggest taking your time with each puzzle. The ones I missed were only three and it took about 3 seconds of video total to find the missing link. If you are a bit like me you will hate that you were 99% done with the solution and didn't wait for the last "struck of lightning" in your head. Then again, time is money, so choose whatever.
I comprised a list of those I didn't have the patience for so you can check it later if you will get stuck:[spoiler]1. Managing Resources - I haven't found a way how to create more cubes. It's dead simple if you know how to do it. You need to close a border of a 3x3 rectangle and the middle piece will appear. 2. Dev room - Hitting a Wall - some puzzles need cubes to be on top of lasers, however, this one needed the exact opposite.  3. Dev room - Laying The Foundation - there are multiple solutions to this, but no consistent one. For me, it was a mixture of two. [/spoiler]

83982964.review:
What happens when an artist/mathematician/psychologist does drugs and decides to draw up a puzzle game? Antichamber happens. No other puzzle game matches Antichamber for the mind games it plays with the player, and it does all this with minimalism and simplicity at its forefront. Somehow, this works. The puzzles will stick in your mind for quite a while, and its difficulty curve does a great job keeping the player engaged and curious.

There's not too much of a plot here; you're plopped into a map hub room. One wall has game options and controls which are interactive (removing the need for a menu), another has an inspirational saying, a third has a rudimentary map, and the fourth has a big window showing the exit door. In order to enter the game, the player has to choose a room from the map and then go from there.

There's not too much to explain about the puzzles. You'll eventually find a tool that allows you to manipulate colored blocks in order to block beams or make walkways, but most of the rooms will have multiple solutions based on your actions. For example, you might find something that tells you to walk. Walking will produce one result, while running another. Maybe turning around and leaving will elicit a third exit. What Antichamber does is manipulate the environment to move you to an entirely different room or to change something without you seeing it, and it does it so well that you won't notice until it's too late. The joy in the game is finding all the solutions to a room and seeing where it takes you. And if you want to go back there, it's as simple as pressing escape and selecting the room again from the map hub.

The environments are pretty spartan, even though they are a masterclass in designing non-Euclidean spaces. More inspirational messages dot the walls before and after rooms, and lighting and colors help the player quickly identify important landmarks and doors, even from a distance. As some downsides to the game, a lot of it is black-on-white which is hard on my eyes and forces me to take breaks before I end up with a headache. Another is the lack of decent sound; there is a mix of ambient sounds and music, but they aren't memorable and just kind of blend into the walls as you won't notice it after an hour or so. The third (and a personal opinion) is a particular texture which is a giant eye. That thing is massively creepy, but requires you to [spoiler]stare at it[/spoiler] to beat the game. I hate it, and in one particular room, ALT+F4'd right out of the game after one showed up out of nowhere. I wouldn't care if it looked like a normal eye, but the way it's drawn just keeps me from replaying this more than I do.

Another complaint is that the game is short. Like, 10 hours max, less if you're skilled at puzzlers. Finally, the map in the map hub needs a legend. I don't believe you should have to search up what the symbols mean in order to know where you went or where you came from, but you should be able to figure it out after a bit. But overall, Antichamber is a great puzzle game. I don't think it's worth $20, but on sale or as a gift it's definitely one you should grab.

83504492.review:
Antichamber is a game that can make you hate yourself as a player. A strange endorsement to be sure, but this is a game that doesn't teach you how to play. It teaches you how YOU play. It's a puzzle game purely about observation. If you're stuck, it's generally because you haven't been paying close enough attention.

The visuals are unique and striking, and the sound design perfectly captures the surreal nature of the environment. Every aspect of the AV design is also a clue to the nature of the puzzle before you. The clever use of color and shapes also means that you are never lost, even if it seems like you are.

The gameplay is designed to upend your expectations, and being an experienced player can actually be a detriment to progression as your preconceived notions direct you towards incorrect assumptions. The frustration comes because you're wrestling with your own brain as you unravel the ways in which your own thought process prevents you from moving forward. 

The joy of playing comes when you change your own brainwaves, and suddenly everything falls into place. Perhaps a particularly tricky puzzle or two will slow you down, but you always feel like you're playing against yourself and not the game. 

Highly recommended, but remember to be kind to yourself as you play!

82466811.review:
This is one of the best games I've ever played, period.

More importantly, [i]Antichamber[/i] is, I think, the apex of what gaming is supposed to be about. It's an extremely tight puzzle that respects the player. The whole game is a trick box, and not a single polygon of it is wasted. There's no filler, nothing is arbitrary. The laconic presentation reinforces the feeling: you're here for the puzzles, and every single one of them is worth it.

Every. Single. One.

Unlike the vast majority of puzzle games, [i]Antichamber[/i] does everything to avoid self-repetition. There are no 'series' or 'types' of puzzles, no 'stages' here; sure, some principles and tricks repeat themselves, but most puzzles are unique. A [i]Talos Principle[/i]-like "you get less keys than doors" puzzle? One. Jumping pads? Seen twice. Unlocking a door by breaking a chain of cubes into several pieces in a labyrinth? Seen twice — before you find a mathematically unsolvable one.

It's not unsolvable, of course. It just tricks you into thinking you've found another puzzle in a series, while in truth the principle behind it is different this time.

This is what [i]Antichamber[/i] excels at, and this is what makes it brilliant: most puzzles in the game — and there are quite a lot — have very simple solutions and demand lateral thinking rather than counting or sleuth of hand. Found a ladder? Actually, you need to go through a wall. A jumping platform facing a ledge? Actually, you need to jump in another direction [i]through[/i] a ladder. A floor-less room?

Have you tried using the hint hanging above you as a physical object?

There are some unlocks that make progress possible and add new rules, but very few of them. Most of the game's variety hinges on the insane inventiveness of the puzzles, redirecting attention, and toying with the player. As a result, every single rooms becomes a unique challenge — and solving each of them feels [i]great.[/i]

The closest comparison I can make is [i]The Witness[/i] — clearly taking a lesson or two from [i]Antichamber's[/i] book. It's another puzzle game that also emphasizes wholeness, unexpected solutions, and where nothing is random. [i]The Witness[/i] has a much more chic presentation and does some things better, like teaching new rules (it took me way, way too long to get adjusted to how the Red Gun works). And yet even [i]The Witness[/i], however great, pales in comparison; its series of similar puzzles seem clunky, same-y and unnecessary.

[i]Antichamber[/i] isn't perfect. Some abilities are a bit clunky (like shifting cubes), the very ending has a puzzling jumping challenge that doesn't fit the game's tone, and it's also very hard to get back to if you've abandoned it for like a week. But these are all minor points.

It's a great game. You should play it. Everyone should. It requires zero special skills, only ingenuity, logic, perceptiveness, and the ability to think outside the box. This is an absolute paragon of what puzzle games should be about — and one of the best uses of gaming medium I've ever seen.

82459828.review:
Reviewing puzzle games is quite difficult. You either get the right "eureka moments" and feel like a genius, or the puzzles just don't click with you and you feel like an idiot and have a terrible time. For Antichamber, I am unfortunately in the latter category of players.

I can get roughly halfway through the game before it starts losing me (or I assume its halfway; the only way I can tell is that I have half the picture board filled up and unlocked the "Glass Half Full" picture - which you get [spoiler] the 2nd time you reach the fake exit [/spoiler] , and after solving a few puzzles involving [spoiler] the green gun [/spoiler] ). I wish I was smart enough to figure out what the game wants me to do. Even after getting fed up, acknowledging my inadequacy, and following a walkthrough; I still feel like the answers to the rest of the puzzles are pulled out of thin air.

I honestly wish I understood this game enough to enjoy it. I'm sure that you'll have an absolutely incredible time if the logic clicks with you. I will recommend this game, despite being immensely frustrated with it, for this exact reason. Just because I had a terrible time with it doesn't mean you will. I recommend maybe watching the first ~20-30 minutes of a lets play or something similar before buying, just so you know what you're getting yourself into (and spoiling the introductory puzzles doesn't seem to be too big of a deal - although it definitely ruins a bit of the magic, which some people will not appreciate).

82230878.review:
When you engage with a puzzle game you want that Eureka moment. Though in Antichamber you rarely get that moment. Most problems you can just stumble into the answer before you feel the need to stop and think. Others you stop and think just to realize that the answer is extremely simple, but just abstracted by a perspective trick.

Think about the first 2 minutes of Portal, where you had to really wrap your mind around the idea of portals to progress. Then the rest of the game you proceed to solve puzzles of growing complexity surrounding this one deep gimmick. Well Antichamber has the same idea, but instead of creating one strong gimmick and making puzzles around it, Antichamber creates dozens of surface level gimmicks and then changes the gimmick every room. It doesn't give you that same sense of progression. Just effort, or luck.

And more shitty quotes than a christian influencer.

79721531.review:
Whoever reads this, please don't watch any walkthroughs or guides, the game might drive you crazy but that's part of the experience! I had to hold myself back too.

I bought this game due to all the positive reviews I've seen here. Started it once, but dropped pretty quickly since I was not in the mood of puzzle games. I just revisited it after a while and finally finished it. I hardly can compare this game to any other one. 

This was an experience. Somewhat like life is. I can only recommend it!

Like in real life you question things: shall you believe in what you see and the thoughts and concepts you had about the world and your environment? These questions will linger with you throughout the whole journey. And as you happen to get to know the world around you, you will get more experienced, you can tackle the challenges you were not able to before. With the experience you can reach new places, and new places come with new tools. These tools can help you greatly and what was difficult earlier becomes one of the most easiest tasks you've ever seen. You will revisit these unsolvable challenges several times (within the game and life as well), but with the skillset, experience and tools you collected throughout your journey they are not impossible anymore.

The game is not holding your hands by any means. Whatever signs you see you shall listen to them, all of them have a purpose. The game will provide you philosophical ideas which have hidden hints and also things to bring with you to real life. You have to learn, question things, and yes, you will be driven crazy sometimes, but so does life with us.

78848856.review: I have no doubt that many will compare Antichamber to The Witness, and with good reason; much like The Witness, Antichamber is filled with peculiar mechanics that are gradually revealed to the player through clues strewn across a non-linear world. However, despite the comparison, this game lacks the visuals and polish of The Witness, opting instead for a unique but somewhat dull black and white aesthetic. The game is full of "aha!" moments, where solving one puzzle suddenly makes you realise how to solve something similar on the other side of the world. The world is very maze-like and confusing, and often changes around you when you're not looking, making it feel vast and alien. All in all it's a fun game if you have the patience for it; some of the puzzles can be quite frustrating and it's easy to get stuck. I particularly enjoyed the ending but I don't think I'll be going for 100% anytime soon.

78604152.review: Antichamber is an interesting experience. On one hand its unique with many twists and turns that forces you to think hard about every corner you take, on the other hand its an open exploration game with no narrative or goal. While I found the game enjoyable, I would not recommend it for its price. The graphics are pretty bland, eye hurting and the game is pretty old. 78566825.review:
First off, this game is embarrassingly lacking in controls for both motion sickness and accessibility. You cannot disable view bobbing. You can only choose from THREE preset mouse sensitivity settings. You can only completely disable ALL sound - no separate controls for music, ambiance, and effects/feedback. You cannot remap colors in a game dependent on colors.

This game is presented as an open-ended puzzle exploration game. There is, apparently, a path you need to (loosely) follow to unlock tools and learn mechanics - but the game makes no attempt to nudge you to this path or indicate that you literally cannot solve the puzzle you're working on, no matter how long you plug away at it.

In fact, the in-game map has a ton of different icons that are both not explained with any sort of key and completely out of line with standard UI affordances. That flashing area isn't a suggested next puzzle - it's where you last were. 

As a result, if you get off the "intended" track early on, you will spend a lot of time banging your head against currently impossible puzzles until you realize there *IS* a necessary order, falling through space surrounded by unavoidable flashing colors, walking your little view-bobbing body in circles through hallways trying to locate more puzzles you CAN complete, and trying to distinguish between "small" and "large" squares (the difference is a handful of pixels) on a map three or four times your height.

As for the puzzles themselves: They were fine, if easy. The ones I had the tools to solve mostly flew by with no challenge, either because they were easy or because I accidentally found "the catch." I didn't get any satisfying "aha!" moments, but I also didn't play long.

Some people might love the meta-puzzle of determining what you are supposed to tackle in what order. Personally, between the lack of hints, misleading interface, smarmy posters, and nausea, I found it a downright infuriating waste of time.

Even at 50% off, I don't recommend this game.

The only positive notes I have are the simplistic art style, and the ambient music. 

I purchased due to raving reviews and being a fan of puzzle brain teasers. What I found out after about an hour of game play, is that there is literally zero story, very few mechanics at all to keep the game engaging, and (the greatest sin when it comes to puzzle games) after you acquire the first "tool" to use, several puzzles throughout the rest of the game have no clues as to the solution what-so-ever. Rather, you have to accidently do the right thing. For instance, not looking away from a particular wall as you move about the room, otherwise the door never appears, and there is no indication of this anywhere. I would refund my money in a heartbeat if I could.

77141510.review:
I will be honest.  When I first played Antichamber I didn’t like it.  The visuals put me off, not because I wanted better visuals but because I had this dumb notion that if the graphics were not good then how could I trust that the puzzles were watertight?  Once I finally overcame this utter stupidity, I was ready to play Antichamber.  Not all puzzle games need to be visually awesome like Talos, Witness and Portal.  I honestly don’t know what I was thinking.  Maybe I was high…..but I couldn’t have been high because when I started getting into Antichamber I felt like I was REALLY high….like call me an ambulance, my brain is turning into jelly, high.

Don’t be like me.  Please, if you like amazing puzzle games, play Antichamber for more than 3 hours.  You have to cross that threshold.  Let getting the blue gun be like “somewhere outside Barstow on the edge of the desert,” and then you can really dive deep into the rabbit hole.

[h1] PROS [/h1]

[list]+  incredibly complex, yet simple.  Yes you will be baffled at the start.  Don’t worry.  That’s the point.  Antichamber wants you to take everything you think you know about puzzle games, maps, geometry, physics and even life itself and take a step to the left into the 5th dimension.  Up is down, down is strawberry jam and backwards is yes.  Antichamber will not allow you to take full control until the very end and will do its utmost to marinade your brain for as long as possible.  But at the right time you will be Neo in The Matrix and you will laugh at how all these puzzles confused you at first.[/list]

[list]+  experimentation.  So if I pull a cube on the x-y axis I can move it into position to open a door!  Awesome!  Wait….this is just a crazy idea but what would happen if I pulled it along the z-axis?  Would that even work?  The only way to advance in Antichamber is to be creative, think outside the box and don’t be limited by your own imagination.  You will find yourself up against impossible odds…..and quite frankly they are impossible by definition because they defy the laws of physics, so thinking about them rationally just won’t do.  You need to figure out your own lifehacks to this bizarre dimension.[/list]

[list]+  wait….are those electrons….pigeons?  The sounds in Antichamber are fantastic.  The music is great and is so subtle as to not take you out of the game or to give you a false hope you are gaining traction in a certain area.  The whole soundboard and soundtrack is sublime.  Mad flashing electrons flutter around like pigeons in a coop, you will fall through huge holes to crashing thunder and land in a puddle of water despite everything being white walls and floors with almost no frills attached.[/list]

[h1] CONS [/h1]

[list]-  difficulty curve.  While most puzzlers start small and scaffold you up, Antichamber, well, does the anti of that and starts big and then the game gets easier over time.  This was incredibly frustrating for me because I didn’t know if what I was trying was even correct and I didn’t know if I could trust the programming or puzzles of the game.  Were there glitches and bugs?  Was the puzzle logical?  I can say now looking back that yes, the game is solid but I see a ton of friends who own this game who never made it past the 90 minute mark.  Either they farmed it for cards or they just gave up.  And I totally understand that.[/list]

[list]- am I doing this right? There are no cheevos for Antichamber.  So I think I did all the extra stuff?  But I’m not sure.  This game is very much like The Witness in that the rewards for completing the hard tasks is the knowledge that you completed them but even in The Witness there are 2 cheevos.  One for completing the game and then one for COMPLETING THE GAME.[/list]   

[h1] THE CONCLUSION [/h1]

Antichamber is an incredible game.  The poor developer Alexander Bruce was the only developer and he got so burnt out by the game it looks like he has given it all up and is now a regular software engineer for a tech company.  Even if this is the only game he ever makes it will stand as a testament to how insane you can push the limits of something and people will still manage to unravel your madness and not only will they solve it…..they will enjoy it.

I am so happy I pushed through Antichamber.  Don’t be like 90 minute Antichamber me.  Challenge your mind and defeat String Theory.

76739262.review: A puzzle typically has many parts (point a, point b, point c, point d...), and there's a specific thing you need to do in order to reach the next point based on the information you have from what you previously figured out (don't get me wrong, I love puzzles for being like that) and this game RIPPED APART the typical meaning of a puzzle, and do I love that they did that? YES. This game feels like both an adventure and a series of puzzles, but it doesn't need to be in a systematic order. The fact that the puzzle doesn't have an order (except for block guns) makes you feel as if you're in the void, but it's just so... relaxing. Straightforward thinking gets you nowhere in this game, and instead you have to break the boundaries of rationality by not only using reasoning, but also imagination. This might make no sense, but when I explore in this game and encounter puzzles I feel like my mind is all over the place but also nowhere, and it does not disturb me, it's mesmerizing. The art style perfectly fits with the 'void-like' atmosphere of the game, and how it's simultaneously simplistic and complicated. The music almost feels sleep-inducing, but it's so relaxing that it just makes me forget about my mental exhaustion... it helps my mind think like crazy and stay calm at the same time. I think every aspect of this game's design is all too well-calculated, and it is deserving of more popularity among the Steam community and Puzzle gaming community. The price might be a little rough, but if you have plenty steam money or find that the game is on sale (I had to buy it when on sale), you really should buy it and experience the same serene (and HOW-DO-I-SOLVE-THIS) experiences that I had when playing this game

75979638.review: Not only is it a puzzle game, it's a mindscrewy puzzle game where the rooms literally warp the fabric of space and time. cubbyholes that are bugger on the inside, stairs and hallyways that endlessly repeat, doorways that lead to oen room when you look at it and then another when you don't, etc. Anyone who enjoyed Portal will also enjoy this, I guarantee it.

75892365.review:
Hi-rez first-person 4D exploration game.  That is not a typo.   You are exploring a space that defies normal geometry trying to find the exit.  Maybe.  You're not given a lot of information.  Just a central room you can return to at will, a map in that room to chart your progress, and a door marked EXIT behind a glass wall.

Oh.  And there's a countdown timer.

This game is made to mess with you.  There are places in it where you can go along a path, than backtrace your steps and not return to where you started.  There are places where you can make ten right turns in quick succession and not be looping.  There is at least one door that always closes when you look at it.  Cubes that show different contents depending on which side you look at.  Floors that aren't.  Steps that may be.

Then there are the motivational posters.  Sometimes they give hints on what you're supposed to do to get past some puzzling situation.  Sometimes they try to encourage.  Sometimes they come off as smug.  Examples include "Failure to succeed is not failure to progress."  "Sometimes what you come back to is not the same as what you left."  They are collectible, in that there's a status wall at the center of the game that tracks which ones you've encountered.

It's pretty.  It's an art piece.  It's entertaining.  A chunk of work went into designing it all, I'm sure.  But I got it in a HB bundle, and I don't see myself spending the current store price of $19.99 for it.  It's worth experiencing, but experience it when it's on sale.

75560144.review:
I don't think I've ever down-voted an "overwhelmingly positive" game.  People keep using words like rewarding, interesting, and awesome, and I'm trying hard to see it, but I just don't see it.  First I thought it maybe just wasn't for me, but I absolutely love games like Portal and The Turing Test.  I thought maybe I was just mad because it was too hard, but I love minimalist puzzles of all difficulties from Zork to Tametsi, and I routinely marathon through unconventional adventures with no hints.  I thought maybe it was too psychological and non-linear, but I love The Stanley Parable and The Beginner's Guide.

So I pushed myself for several hours past the point of losing interest early, and I actually covered a lot more ground, unlocking what appears (on the wall that tracks you) to be over 2/3 of the game, having solved over half of that.  I did not find the new abilities interesting, and I did not enjoy seeing what came next.  What am I supposed to do with a game where the puzzle solutions don't feel satisfying to me and the environment doesn't interest me enough to even use a walk-through so I can see it?

So I'm writing this review to say that even if you like hard, psychological, unconventional, minimalist first-person puzzles, that doesn't mean you'll like this game.  The best thing I can say about it is that I kind of feel like the game reviewed me and found me uninteresting and unsatisfying, so I guess I can praise the developers for pulling off a pretty good trick.

73828670.review:
Antichamber is a very unique game, both visually and gameplay-wise. The mindscrew/puzzle aspects remind me of Portal, which I'd imagine was intentional on the part of the developers. But what makes it so unique is the amount of freedom the puzzle aspects allow for, especially with the different abilities you obtain throughout the game. The gameplay encourages players to test things out and see what works and what doesn't, and sometimes if you're smart you can even sequence break! (I know I did once by accident.) Otherwise, all the awesome easter eggs and gameplay quirks made this game very engaging and honestly very replayable. I might come back to it again at some point, I'd love to see how much I could mess with the physics/puzzle aspects to break the game even more. >:)

Would highly recommend if you enjoy puzzle games. Literally my only criticism is that I would want more of it. Despite being chock-full of content, overall it's still a 5-hour game. I would [i]love[/i] to see more, if possible.

73778878.review: Nice challenging puzzles, got stuck on some of them for some time, and none of the puzzles required RNG to surpass them, which it's a great thing. 73578054.review: This, The Witness and Baba Is You are games (although thematically and mechanically unrelated) that I would describe as overwhelmingly smart puzzles. Not only do you feel like a genius for figuring out the solution, you are also awestruck about the thought and ingenuity that went into designing the puzzles. If you want to teach your brain new ways to work with complex abstractions, these are the games for you. The Witness is like learning tp talk in a new language based entirely on tracing lines on a grid. Baba Is You makes you rethink what you know about inherent properties and causality. And finally Antichamber makes you broaden you horizon to think outside of classic euclidian geometry and spatial dimensions. If you like the other two games, get this without thinking. If you don't know any of them, Antichamber is probably the best way to start. Highly recommended!

73360321.review:
This game is really weird and confusing, overall every section of it features a neat puzzle, which most of the times feels satisfying to solve, although a couple of them might be a little bit frustrating if you try too hard all at once (taking a break really helps sometimes). If it were only for the puzzles, I don't know if I would recommend getting this game at full price (but I definitely would recommend it on sale), the puzzles are not what makes this game great, in my opinion. So if all you want is a Portal-style puzzle game, then you probably wouldn't enjoy this game as much as Portal.

Instead, what I personally really enjoyed is the atmosphere of the game. You are basically wandering in what looks like a strange """""lab""""", full of strange shapes and objects (which most of the time are only marginally related to the actual puzzle), without any explanation about why you are there, or what is the actual goal. Speaking of the goal, there are a lot of puzzles, but only 4 sets of puzzles, plus the final part, are actually required to finish the game. Everything else is just there, but there is also no way to know if a certain puzzle is one of this 4 (you only know that for sure [spoiler] once you collect an upgrade for your gun. [/spoiler] ). Again, this may be really frustrating if you prefer a more linear story such as in Portal. However, each section of the "lab" comes with its own twist, not only in the form of new puzzles, but also because there are a lot of black squares scattered around the whole map. These squares all contain images and a brief description, that are somehow related to the puzzle, but most of the times also have a deeper meaning. [spoiler] One of these squares is actually revealed when the fake 90-minute timer in the hub runs out. [/spoiler] Finally, there are some hidden purple cubes all over the map, which you can look for if you are a completionist [spoiler] although there is no reward in-game for finding them all [/spoiler].

So, this is a puzzle game, but the exploration part is arguably even more important. In the end, playing this game should feel more like reading a book. A very confusing book, sure, but ultimately one of those books that you end up appreciating, and maybe read again. Or maybe a book you'll NEED to read multiple times before "understanding" it. In my opinion, this is how you should approach this game to enjoy it the most. [spoiler] Or just consider it an LSD-less way to have an LSD trip. That also works. [/spoiler]

Because of the layout of the "world" you cant ever even be sure if you've ever actually completed a "path" or if you missed something, or if you need to come back later once you've done something else. So you spend a couple hours backtracking and getting lost and eventually you give up.

It was fun for about 1-2 hours and then I just got annoyed with the lack of any direction or concrete signs of real progress.

73066209.review:
Antichamber is a mind bending puzzle experience that inserts you into a M.C. Escher like dimension, forcing you to learn new abilities and find your way out.

Do not mistake my use of "forcing" for unenjoyment. The sheer mystery and ambiance of this game, mixed with the feeling of everything coming together as you go along propelled me to complete this game, and feel a great sense of achievement for doing so. 

I've had this game for years, but have never truly completed it until now. I definitely recommend Antichamber!
